n. Attack all around. A person who launches an all-around attack. A person who takes charge of the situation and is able to make others obey him or her. This Internet slang term comes from the Japanese ACG culture, especially Boy’s Love-themed works. The term is often used positively to describe a natural leader.

n. Attack all around+oneself. This Internet slang term has the same meaning as 總攻 [zǒng gōng]. It is often used to emphasize the leadership role in a group or a romantic relationship that one possesses.

<Expression> Slant the building. Let me digress. 樓 [lóu] as an Internet slang term refers to a post and its replies in online discussions. When you want to digress, you use this expression as a reminder to other Internet users.

adj./n. Reality+fulfilling. This Internet slang term comes from the Japanese Internet slang term “リア充” and refers to people who live a fulfilling life without ACG (Anime, Comic and Games) or the Internet.
adj. Epic poem-level. This Internet slang term means reaching a very high degree.
n. Goose+factory. Penguin factory. Tencent. This Internet slang term refers to Tencent whose logo is a penguin.

column3: <Expression> Kiss and hug and raise above the head [to show affection]. This expression is often used to describe one’s love for pets or loved ones.

adj./n. Fat+indoorsy. 1) Fat and inactive. 2) A fat and indoorsy person who prefers watching movies or TV dramas or playing video games instead of going out. This Internet slang term is often used to describe oneself.
<Expression> To poke one’s own eyes. To blind oneself (because you can’t bear seeing something) . This expression is often used to comment on artworks that are visually appalling or extremely shoddy.
adj. Tight+dirty. Nervous. This Internet slang term means 緊張 [jǐn zhāng] “nervous.” It mimics the Taiwanese Mandarin accent.
<Expression> Well done! This expression is sometimes used to praise well-executed pranks or repartee.
n./adj. […Of] our home. This Internet slang term is often used before a star’s name. Fans often use the term to describe their idolset and/or the fan group they belong to.
<Expression> Save the child. This expression is often used when asking for help. “The child” refers to oneself.
n. Female driver. A female who is skilled in things such as gaming and telling dirty jokes. This Internet slang term is the female version of 老司機 [lǎo sī jī].

n. Chen+make a big fortune. Chen Dafa. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Taiwanese actress Ivy Chen or Chen Yihan. She gave the nickname to herself. It is a nickname given to her by her, because she thought it was a funny nickname.
<Expression> Fleeing immediately after showing off or acting like I’m better than I really am. This expression is often used for self-mockery.
adj. Naughty.
n. Some+treasure. This Internet slang term is a euphemism for Taobao. It is often used sarcastically or humorously without openly advertising the Alibaba shopping site.
v. Awkward+dance. Dance clumsily or awkwardly, often for comical effect.

column3: <Expression> The appearance of being married to love. This expression is often use to celebrate a couple’s love. Their happiness are attributed to the fact that they are deeply in love.
interj. This interjection is often used to indicate confusion with a meaning similar to “What?” Also, it can be used at the end of a sentence to emphasize one’s statement.
n. Destroy+tyrant. Thanos. Thanos is a fictional character appearing in American comic books published by Marvel Comics.
n. Hero, fighter. This Internet slang term is used humorously to address a fellow Internet user. Sarcasm is sometimes applied.

column3: n. The invisible poverty-stricken population, people whose consumption exceeds their income.
v. Break away from+fan. To stop being [a celebrity’s] fan.
n. The leg-shaking gang. People with jittery legs while sitting.
n. Evil tendencies. This Internet slang term refers to the antisocial inclinations that people display online or offline.

n. Sister Calculus. Here, “calculus” means a concretion of minerals formed within the body, especially in the kidney or gallbladder. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Jessie J because 結石 [jié shí] “calculus” sounds like “Jessie.”

column3: <Expression> Good looks follow a fixed pattern, but it’s rare to find an interesting soul. This expression became popular in 2017.
adj. Able to endure tearing. 1) Nice; 2) resilient. This Internet slang term was made popular by Chinese reality TV show Keep Running which is famous for its game of “tearing name tags.”

column2: mó rén de xiǎo yāo jing
column3: <Expression> Bothersome little elf. This expression is often said by a domineering male lead to his titillating young girlfriend in Internet novels. It is often followed by “what should I do with you?”
v. Hoist+high+high. To hoist [often one’s intimate partner] with both hands above one’s head to show affection. This Internet slang term is often used humorously to express one’s love.

<Expression> Send you to [the section of] hot comments [which are often automatically stuck to the top]. This expression is often used to express one’s approval of a comment on a social media post because it is well-written or funny. The Internet users who use this expression usually click “like” on the comment too to make it pinned to the top of the comment section.

<Expression> Send you onto the wall. Send you to [the section of] hot comments [which are often automatically placed at the top]. This expression is often used to express one’s approval of a comment on a social media post because it is well-written or funny. The Internet users who use this expression usually click “like” on the comment too to make it pinned to the top of the comment section.
The emoticon looks like a sad face with a gaping mouth and a pair of teary eyes. It is often used to express sadness.
adj. Cool, awesome. The original meaning of the word is “the harmful effect of something,” but as an Internet slang term, it is an alternative way of saying 牛逼 [niú bī].

<Expression> The whole segment collapses. [Of a person or performance] to fail completely. This expression was first made popular by singer Xue Zhiqian aka Joker Xue on the variety TV show The Mars Intelligence Agency. It is often used to tease others or oneself.
n. Doglike man. A doglike man is athletic, outgoing, fun-loving, and a bit needy. This slang term comes from Japanese and is often used to label a type of boyfriends.
n. Wolflike man. A wolflike man is calm, domineering, committed, and a bit hard to control. This slang term is often used to label a type of boyfriends.
n. Catlike man. A catlike man is independent, artistic, gentle, and a bit effeminate. This slang term comes from Japanese. This slang term is often used to label a type of boyfriends.

<Expression> Adorably mad. This expression describe the way a cute little child or a young person whose appearance or personality resembles a cute little child’s gets mad. You think it is cute not scary when such a person gets mad.
n. Little wolfdog. A woman’s young, dashing, and responsible boyfriend.

column3: <Expression> [You don’t] break up with such a boyfriend. Are you saving him for the next Chinese New Year? This expression is often used to criticize a man who physically or emotionally abuses his girlfriend.

v. Hype+CP [Couple]. [Of the media] to hype two entertainers of either opposite sexes or the same sex as a couple, often for business purposes. Many TV dramas, films, and reality TV shows like pairing up entertainers to attract public attention.

column3: <Expression> This fellow student, when I am acting all snotty, please don’t talk [to give me away]. Hey dude, don’t stop me when I’m bragging.
n. Magic simultaneity. This Internet slang term is often used to describe the situation where people display the same body language.
n. Poo. Dad. This Internet slang term means “dad”. It mimics the Taiwanese Mandarin accent.
n. Sackcloth. Mom. This Internet slang term means “mom”. It mimics the Taiwanese Mandarin accent.

n. Apricot pink, yellowish pink. This Internet slang term is an affectionate nickname for Ashin or Chen Hsin-hung or Chen Xinhong, the vocalist of the Taiwanese band Mayday. The nickname and his Chinese first name are semi-homophones.
n. New album. This Internet slang term is short for 新專輯 [xīn zhuān jí].
n. Roaring hierarch. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Taiwanese actor Steve Ma because of his hysterical acting style at the early stages of his career.

n. Roaring style. This Internet slang term refers to an Internet writing style which is replete with exclamation marks and expressions like 有木有 [yǒu mù yǒu] “Correct?” to strongly express one’s thought.

<Expression> Leg+play+year. This expression is short for “I can play with her legs for a whole year.” It is adapted from the line “Look at that pair of legs. I can play with them for a whole night”, said by a gangster to an undercover police officer’s girlfriend, in the movie “Century of the Dragon.” This expression is a typical example of the male gaze.
n. Mandate of Heaven+Circle. Safe zone. This Internet slang term originated from the game Knives Out.
n. Little+transparent. Nobody. This Internet slang term is often used by fans who don’t have a large presence in the fandom to describe themselves.
adj. Flamboyant, showy, conspicuous. This Internet slang term is often used sarcastically.
n. Aunt+smile. The smile of an aunt. This Internet slang term is often used by female fans to describe their affectionate and indulgent smile at their male idol.
n. Poison+only. Fans who like only one member of an idol group and exhibit hostility against the other members of the group.
n. map+cannon. Discrimination against people from a certain region.

n. Seed. Torrent file. As an Internet slang term it often refers to a torrent file. In the BitTorrent file distribution system, a torrent file is a computer file that contains metadata about files and folders to be distributed, and usually also a list of the network locations of trackers, which are computers that help participants in the system find each other and form efficient distribution groups. A torrent file does not contain the content to be distributed; it only contains information about those files, such as their names, sizes, folder structure, and cryptographic hash values for verifying file integrity.
v. Retreat+dispel. Go away. This Internet slang term comes from the Japanese word “逃げ去る.” It is often used to drive away something or someone unwanted.

n. Indigenous & Unrefined+idol. Indigenous & Unrefined Idol. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Idol Producer, a Chinese reality boy group survival show produced by iQiyi.  The show was criticized for copying Produce 101 illegally.

n. Indigenous & Unrefined+create. Indigenous & Unrefined Create. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Produce 101, a Chinese reality television show spinoff of the South Korean television show Produce 101. The Chinese name of the show is literally Create 101. The show was criticized for the caliber of its contestants as well the quality of production.

v. Wash+white. <ACG Terminology> This term originally described the situation where an ostensibly negative character suddenly turned into a positive character. Now it means “[of people or organizations] to get rid of a bad reputation by disseminating positive but embellished stories about themselves.”

v. Wash+floor. This Internet slang term is from the 2004 movie “Kung Fu Hustle” where a Deadly Axe Gang leader asked the members to clean the blood on the floor after a gang fight. The term means to whitewash, to cover up or gloss over scandals, vices or crimes.
adj. Sparta. Crazy. [Of a person] going nuts. This Internet slang term comes from the video “This Is Sparta,” a parody of the movie Meet the Spartans (2008).
n. While the original meaning of the word is “ending of a piece of writing;concluding line of an article,” as an Internet slang term, it means “jackass. ” It is a euphemism for SB/傻逼 [shǎ bī].
<Expression> If you don’t like [what I’m saying], don’t rant [against me]. This expression is often used before expressing one’s opinion online.
n. Teacher He. This Internet slang term is a nickname for He Jiong, a Chinese television host, singer, actor, director and a former Arabic lecturer in Beijing Foreign Studies University.
n. Teacher Chen. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Hong Kong actor Edison Chan aka Chen Guanxi and Taiwanese singer-songwriter Cheer Chen aka Chen Qizhen.
n. Brain+ax. Tiger. This Internet slang term mimics the pronunciation of 老虎 [lǎo hǔ] “tiger” with accents that do not differentiate between “h” and “f” in Pinyin.

n. Fighting+ethnic group. The fighting nation. Russia, Russian people. This Internet slang term emphasizes Russians’ gallantry and the mind-boggling humor resulting from their bravery. It is often used humorously.

column2: yì bú yì wài? jīng bù jīng xǐ?
column3: <Expression> Was that unexpected? Were you pleasantly surprised? This expression is often used humorously to comment on a surprising plot twist or an unexpected turn of events.
adj. Explode+shatter. [Of one’s acting, singing, writing, etc.] awesome, breathtaking.

n. Beckon+black+body type. The criticism-inducing body type. This Internet slang term is often used to describe celebrities who are easy targets for criticism or vilification by Internet users. It is often used by celebrities for self abasement.
n. Double standard+dog. A double-standard dog. This Internet slang term is a derogatory term for people who are considered practicing a double standard.

column2: jiàn guó hòu bù xǔ chéng jīng
column3: <Expression> [Of someone or an animal] forbidden to become a goblin after the foundation of the People’s Republic of China. This expression came from a 2015 rumor that the State Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television of the People’s Republic of China forbade the animal roles in animated series, TV shows, and films set in China after October 1, 1949 to become a goblin or spirit. Now the expression is often used to describe an incredibly smart animal that behaves like human beings or an amusingly adorable person.
n. Feminism+cancer. Feminist cancer. This Internet slang term is a derogatory term for feminists. It is often used by people who loathe feminism and feminists.
n. Feminism+bitch. Feminist bitch. This Internet slang term is a derogatory term for feminists. It is often used by people who loathe feminism and  feminists.

column2: zhōng huá tián yuán nǚ quán
column3: n. Chinese rural feminism. Adapted from 中華田園貓 [zhōng huá tián yuán māo] “Chinese rural cat” and 中華田園狗 [zhōng huá tián yuán gǒu] “Chinese rural dog,” this Internet slang term is a derogatory term for Chinese feminists. It is often used by people who assume that Chinese feminists advocate for women’s rights but evade women’s responsibilities. They also often oppose Chinese feminists’ communication style.

v. Jump+drama. [Of an actor or actress] to give unconvincing performance. The reasons vary. It could be because the viewers are accustomed to seeing the actor or actress cast in a different type of role, because the performer’s previous acting in a similar role left a deeper impression on the audience, or because the storyline is problematic.

column2: yuè nǔ lì, yuè xìng yùn
column3: <Expression> The harder you work, the luckier you are. This inspirational expression recently became more popular as the slogan of Idol Producer, a Chinese reality boy group survival show produced by iQiyi.
n. Gay+honey. [A woman’s] best gay friend. This Internet slang term is often used positively to describe a woman’s sophisticated and compassionate homosexual guy friend.
n. Mushroom+cold. Girl. This Internet slang term is 姑娘 [gū niáng] “girl” in the Lanzhou dialect. It is often used for humorous effect.

n. Class representative. This Internet slang term refers to people who are good at explaining a hot topic for other Internet users. Internet users often call for a “class representative” humorously when they want to understand a complicated issue so that they don’t have to read about it on their own.
n. Trashy+Hui. Trashy Hui. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Hong Kong actor Nick Cheung Ka Fai or Zhang Jiahui because that’s the way he pronounced his name in Mandarin.

<Expression> Society+my+X+brother. My worldly-wise brother/sister X [X is usually one of the characters in the person’s Chinese name]. This expression is often followed by 人狠話不多 [rén hěn huà bù duō] “tough and laconic” to tease someone who puts on airs or pretends to be sophisticated or street-smart.
adj. Worldly, sophisticated, street-smart. This Internet slang term is often used sarcastically.

n. Xie+ear. Xie Ear. This Internet slang term combines the Chinese last name Xie and the word ear. It is an affectionate nickname for American actor Jim Parsons and his role Sheldon Lee Cooper in The Big Bang Theory.

<Expression> The Qing dynasty is long gone. This expression is often used to comment on outmoded and backward ideas redolent of the Qing dynasty. Internet users often lambaste dictatorship and misogyny using this expression.
n. Horse+kill+chicken. Massage. This Internet slang term mimics the pronunciation of the English word “massage.” It is also a funny translation of the Japanese word  マッサージ “masaji/masachi.”

<Expression> Confirmed the look in [his/her] eyes. I can tell from the look. This expression originally came from JJ Lin aka Lin Junjie’s song “Tales of the Red Cliff,” the theme song of the online game Red Cliff. Now it is used humorously to show one’s certainty about something.

n. The virtuous person time = The virtuous person mode.. Derived from the Japanese term 贤者タイム (kenja time—the period after orgasm when a man is free from sexual desire and can think clearly), this Internet slang term refers to the state of feeling peaceful, free from desire, sober-minded or emotionally empty after intensive activities, such as watching a great movie, playing an exciting game, and masturbation.
adj. [Of someone] stooping low and doing unethical things. This Internet slang term is closely related to 節操 [jié cāo] “scruples, moral principles, integrity.”
n. Highlight+moment. One’s most glamorous or head-turning moment.
n. Hammer+brother. Brother Hammer. This Internet slang term is an affectionate nickname for Australian actor Chris Hemsworth because of his titular role in the movie “Thor.”
n. Brain-damaged+fan. Stanners. Zealous fans who blindly worship their idols.
v. To observe furtively. This Internet slang term is widely seen in stickers to reveal that one is a lurker and to remind others to behave themselves (such as not being too cocky).

<Expression> This year’s…are not good. This expression is often used to show disapproval of a certain group of people who did not live up to one’s expectation. The expression mimics the tone of voice of Chinese teachers. Chinese teachers at elementary schools and high schools are famous for degrading all their students as the “worst group of students they’ve ever taught.”
n. IQ tax. This Internet slang term is often used in the phrase “paid the IQ tax” to describe someone who is gullible.
adj. Great, honorable, and correct. This Internet slang term is short for 偉大，光榮，正確 [wěi dà, guāng róng, zhèng què], often used sarcastically.
n. White+Gu. The white Louis Koo. This Internet slang term is the nickname for Hong Kong actor Louis Koo in his untanned era.
n. Black+Gu. The black Louis Koo. This Internet slang term is the nickname for Hong Kong actor Louis Koo after he deliberately got tanned to avoid putting on makeup.
v. Sweet bamboo. Bookmarked. Saved. This Internet slang term is used when you save a social media post for later perusal. 麻竹 [má zhú] sounds like 碼住 [mǎ zhù] “bookmarked.”
v. Horse. Bookmarked. This Internet slang term is used when you save a social media post for later perusal. 馬 [mǎ] and 碼 [mǎ ] are homophones.
<Expression> If you are not convinced, hold it in. This expression is often used to show one’s confidence about one’s ability or argument.
<Expression> If you are not convinced, come and fight [come argue with me]. This expression is often used to show one’s confidence about one’s argument.
v. Stop+update. [Of a program, manga series, podcast, etc.] to stop updating.
v. Explode+hair. To flip out.
n. Male+ticket. Boyfriend. 票 [piào] mimics the Taiwanese Mandarin accent and is short for 朋友 [péng yǒu] “friend(s).”
n. Female+ticket. Girlfriend. 票 [piào] mimics the Taiwanese Mandarin accent and is short for 朋友 [péng yǒu] “friend(s).”

n. Ticket+circle. 1) Friends. 2) [WeChat] Moments, the WeChat news feeds which demonstrate what your friends are up to lately. 票 [piào] mimics the Taiwanese  Mandarin accent and is short for 朋友 [péng yǒu] “friend(s).”

column2: gàng líng bān de xiào shēng
column3: <Expression> Barbell-like laughter. Adapted from 銅鈴般的笑聲 [tóng líng bān de xiào shēng] “copper bell-like laughter,” this expression is often used humorously to describe a rowdy’s laughter.
pronoun. You [guys]. This Internet slang term is used humorously because 乃 [nǎ] is the archaic form of “you.”
v. To tag [someone on social media]. This Internet slang term is often used to precede the name of a person or a group you want to talk to.
n. A celebrity’s status in the entertainment industry.
n. C position. The central position [in photo shooting or video taping, which implies the celebrity’s high status].

n./v. Rush+feet. Feelings. While the original meaning of this word is “to hire oneself to transport goods with one’s own donkey, mule, etc.” As an Internet slang term, it means 感覺 [gǎn jué] “feeling” or “to feel.” It mimics the Northeastern accent for humorous effect.
v. Collect+pictures. To save into one’s personal collection the pictures of one’s idol posted by other people on social media.
n. Personal+goods. Personal opinion that might not be liked by the readers or viewers.

n. Bicker+elf. This Internet slang term is used disapprovingly to describe people addicted to bickering and faultfinding in online discussions. They are aggressive, brash, and always seek to win the argument.

column2: zhèng zài tí dāo gǎn lái de lù shàng
column3: <Expression> [Someone] is carrying a broadsword on his or her way to this place. This expression is used humorously to speculate that someone will be upset about what you are seeing.
v. To mail blades [to the screenwriter]. <ACG> This Internet slang term is often used to imply the audience’s dissatisfaction with the development of a storyline.

column2: zhè shì yí dào chāo gāng tí
column3: <Expression> This is a question that exceeds the scope of the examination guideline. This questions is too hard. This expression is often used humorously to refer to things that are beyond one’s ken or capabilities.
n. Pre-installed filters. This Internet slang term is often used to describe someone who looks beautiful as if he or she carries filters of his or her own.
v. titillate+sex appeal. This Internet slang term refers to flirting with or hitting on someone.
n. Auntie fans. This Internet slang term refers to female fans who are much older than their male idol. They tend to look at the idol as a cute little nephew.
n. Birth mother fans. This Internet slang term refers to female fans who are significantly older than their male idol or who are concerned about their idol’s well-being as if they were his mom.
v. Can, able to. This Internet slang term is a humorous phonetic deviation of 可以 [kě yǐ].

<Expression> Maintain the smile [to mask one’s true feelings]. This expression is often used ironically to reveal that one repressed his or her true feelings under the pressure to maintain good relationships with others. 围笑 [wéi xiào] is a phonetic deviation of 微笑 [wēi xiào] “smile.”
v. To drive a car. To talk dirty. The Internet slang term often describes harmless dirty jokes which probably would not be considered sexual harrassment.

column2: xuán zhuǎn tiào yuè bì zhe yǎn
column3: <Expression> Spin, jump, with eyes closed. This expression comes from Jolin Tsai’s song “Dancing Diva.” Now it is often used humorously, e.g. 打你打到旋轉跳躍閉著眼 “I will hit you to the point where you spin and jump with your eyes closed.”

n. <ACG> Under the skin. The author of the original post that you reshared or commented on. This Internet slang term stems from cosplay. The character you portray is called “over the skin” and you are called “under the skin.” Now it sometimes refers the official account of an entertainer on social media. Such accounts usually attract a large following and entail numerous reshares and comments.

v. To cross out [a word]. This Internet slang term is often used humorously to correct yourself. You usually insert the Internet slang term between the original word and the correction. The original word shows your true intention while the correction is the result of your self-censorship. E.g. I admire my idol’s appearance, cross that out, talent.
v. To push someone down. To push someone onto the bed, floor, etc. and make love to him or her. This Internet slang term is often used by female Internet users to describe their love for a male idol.
adj. [Of someone or something] the first generation. This Internet slang term comes from Japanese.
<Expression> [I’m] so happy that I could fly up.
v. To support myself by holding onto the wall. This Internet slang term describes one’s shock at something that rendered himself or herself unsteady.
<Expression> Help me get onto the wall. Help me become more visible in this online discussion by liking my post.

column2: bù fú qiáng jiù fú nǐ
column3: <Expression> I don’t hold onto the wall; I admire you only. Since 扶 and 服 are homophones, this expression actually means I admire nobody but you. Sometimes it is satirical.
v. Run+reality. [Of people engaging in online dating] to meet in person to see if they like each other offline and want to become a couple.
adj. Big-headed. This Internet slang term is often used in self-mockery.
v. Green. To cheat on [one’s partner].
v. Net+green. To be cheated on by one’s partner who has an affair with someone he or she met on the Internet.
n. Today’s share [of something]. This Internet slang term is used as a cute alternative of “today’s…” or “…of the day.” It looks like a Japanese term but is actually not.

adj. Self-consistent. This Internet slang term stems from Logic and is often used disapprovingly to describe one’s self-justification. The implication is often that the person is actually self-contradictory.

n. Little puppy. Toy boy. This Internet slang term refers to a young male that is the love interest of the opposite sex. It is often used to describe a cute young male idol. Some men protest that the term is sexist and degrades men.

n./adj. White+leftist. This Internet slang term refers to leftists among the white people in Western countries or people holding similar views. As liberals, they typically sympathize with minority groups like queers and the low-income class. They are also concerned about the environment. The term is sometimes used with contempt because of the assumption that white leftists are often from the upper-middle class and have little experience with the groups they care about.
n. Coen+sister-in-law. This Internet slang term is Chinese Internet users’ nickname for Frances McDormand because she is Joel Coen’s wife.

<Expression> Get to know it. This expression is used to invite or request someone to learn more about something. A level of sarcasm is present. The humor involved is that this phrase is originally used widely among sales people in sentences like “Do you want to learn more about [a product]?”
The village. This Internet slang term is a nickname that some mainland Chinese students use to describe their universities in the rural or less cosmopolitan parts of the United States.

n. Bai Qi. One of the main male characters in Love and Producer, a mobile game about dating and relationships.  He is a SWAT officer. His supernatural power is wind field manipulation. This character became popular on China’s social media in December, 2017.

n. Li Zeyan, one of the main male characters in Love and Producer, a mobile game about dating and relationships. He is the CEO of Huarui in the financial services industry. His supernatural power is time manipulation. This character became popular on China’s social media in December, 2017.

column2: tǔ mù sān bān chén tóng xué
column3: n. Student Chen from Class 3 of Civil Engineering. This Internet slang term originally comes from a vlogger’s pranks on male gamers who like trolling online. In the prank, vlogger Bei Lala uses a voice changer to pretend to be a Taiwanese girl and requests the target trolls to sing a song for him. After the guy falls for him, he reveals his gender.

n. Chen Duxiu. As an Internet slang term, it does not refer to Chen Duxiu, a Chinese revolutionary socialist, educator, philosopher, and author, who co-founded the Chinese Communist Party (with Li Dazhao) in 1921, serving from 1921 to 1927 as its first General Secretary.
n./adj. Nolan+black. Christopher Nolan detractors. This Internet slang term is used to describe people who dislike Christopher Nolan’s film style.
v. Accompany+run. To be nominated for an award that one is not to win. This Internet slang term often describes an actor or singer who never wins an award that he or she is constantly nominated for.
v. Sell+gayness. To present oneself or a piece of artwork in a way that appeals to an audience that adore homosexuality.
n. Wood+cutting+exhausting. Exhausting to cut wood. This Internet slang term means “family” because of the similar pronunciation.
adj. Lick+screen+direction. (Of a video or article) created to show one’s admiration for a celebrity’s physical appearance.
v. To become black. (Of one’s public image) to deteriorate as negative news surfaces. This Internet slang term also refers to a good guy turning into a bad guy in a TV show.
n. The eldest cousin sister. This Internet slang term is an affectionate nickname for American actress Jennifer Lawrence and Chinese model Liu Wen.
n. Sweet tea. This Internet slang term is an affectionate nickname for actor Timothée Chalamet.
n. Ancient style. This Internet slang term refers to literature, music, and art that portray or reflect the ancient Chinese style.

n. Dimension+wall. The boundaries of different fields. This Internet slang term stemmed from 次元 [cì yuán]. It is often used humorously and admirably to describe the unexpected connections between disparate fields.
v. Explode+account. [Of a Weibo account] to be deactivated permanently for breaking the community regulations of Sina Weibo.
adj. Dramatic. This Internet slang term sounds like the English word “drama.” It is often used to describe someone who habitually responds to situations in a melodramatic way.
<Expression> Good at [lovemaking] and not needy. This expression comes from the hookup culture in China.
n. A string of three [things]. This Internet slang term is used to describe a string of three things. For example, 素質三連 [sù zhì sān lián] means “a string of three curse words.”

v. Embarrassed+vilify. To slander [a celebrity]. This Internet slang term means to suddenly spread rumors about a celebrity who rarely has scandals. The rumors are usually considered so outlandish that they are embarrassing.

n. Free+patronize+fan. Fans who patronize [a prostitute] for free. Here “prostitute” actually refers to an idol. This Internet slang term is a pejorative term for fans who are not willing to spend money or take part in social media campaigns for their idols. They only want to enjoy the idols’ works for free without making any contribution to the idols’ careers.
n. Gold+owner. Sponsor. This Internet slang term refers to the sponsor of a TV show or other projects.
n. Dad. This Internet slang term is a humorous nickname for rich men that you wished to have as your parents so that you could have their money. For example, Jack Ma is widely dubbed Daddy Jack Ma.

column2: dì zhǔ jiā de shǎ ér zi
column3: n. The landlord’s silly son. This Internet slang term is often used affectionately to describe one’s adorkable male idol.

column2: qǐng kāi shǐ nǐ de biǎo yǎn
column3: <Expression> Please start your performance. Originally overused in talent shows by the judges to invite the contestants to start their performances, this expression became popular around the end of 2016. Now it is often used humorously to allow someone to talk or brag.
n. Heavenly dish. When you say someone is your “heavenly dish,” you mean that person is exactly your type—a person of your dreams.
Equivalent to 那 [nà] n. That. This Internet slang term mimics the Hunan accent for comic effect.
n. Awesome. This Internet slang term mimics the Taiwanese Mandarin accent for comic effect.
<Expression> [I’ve] tested it myself; [it’s] effective. This expression is often used when recommending something.
n. Cloud+sniff+cat. Related to 吸貓 [xī māo] “raise a pet cat,” this Internet slang term refers to cat lovers’ enjoying the cat pictures posted online by other people.
adj. Provincial+cool. This Internet slang term sounds like “too cool.” It refers to the style that accentuates the humor of mundane and unrefined clothes and objects.

v. To save the dignity [for the original poster]. This Internet slang term is used when you leave the first comment on a post that hasn’t been replied for a long time. The purpose of leaving the comment is to cheer up the neglected original poster.

n. Fairy+attack. This Internet slang term is the fans’ nickname for actress Liu Yifei or Crystal Liu in 2015. Liu Yifei is famous for her role in The Return of the Condor Heroes as the beautiful and elegant Xiaolongnü. She also dubbed “Sister Fairy.” The new nickname was originally used to express the fans’ admiration for her dashing and slightly masculine look when dressed in suits.
n. Main character+halo. The halo of the main character. This Internet slang term refers to the pattern in games, films and TV shows that the main characters are unusually lucky in adversity.
n. Dog+head. This Internet slang term refers to the emoticons featuring the head of a dog. The emoticon is often used at the end of a sentence to signify that the remark is ironic or sarcastic.
v. To descend from the sky. This Internet slang term is often used to describe someone or something that suddenly appears out of the blue.

column1: 世界那么大，我想去看看
column2: shì jiè nà me dà, wǒ xiǎng qù kàn kàn
column3: <Expression> The world is so big; I want to go take a look at it. This expression became famous because it was the resignation letter of Gu Shaoqiang, a teacher from Sichuan, in 2015. Her resignation letter caused a buzz on social media because many people resonated with her yearning for traveling.
n. Slash youth. Young people with multiple careers or identities. [Self-proclaimed] versatile young people. This Internet slang term is often used in self description.

column1: 每一个抖腿爱好者的心里. 大概都住著一台缝纫机
column2: měi gè dǒu tuǐ ài hào zhě de xīn lǐ, dà gài dōu zhù zhe yì tái féng rèn jī
column3: <Expression> In the heart of everyone that likes to shake their legs [while sitting] lives a sewing machine. This expression is often used to tease or criticize people with jittery legs while sitting.

<Expression> Poetry and the far-off land. This expression comes from the quote from Zhang Kequn, musician Gao Xiaosong’s mother, “Life is more than resigning to the mundane affairs in life; it is also about poetry and the far-off land.” This quote became popular among Chinese young people under the pressure of high housing prices in big cities. It is often cited to inspire people to stop fretting over not amassing enough material wealth and instead find a place of inner peace through art and travel.
n./adj. Double standard. This Internet slang term is short for 雙重標準 [shuāng chóng biāo zhǔn].
v. To give away one’s age. This Internet slang term is often used when mentioning something that happened a long time ago and pokes fun at the speaker’s age. It is often used in self-mockery.

column2: sù liào huā jiě meì qíng
column3: n. Plastic flowers+sisterhood. Vulnerable or insincere female friendship. Fair-weather friendship. This Internet slang term refers to women who appear to be best friends forever but actually scheme against each other in private.
n. Carry+wok+knight. Scapegoat. This Internet slang term derives from 背鍋 [bēi guō].
n. Has-been+Internet celebrity. A former Internet celebrity who is no longer popular.
n. Baby+mom. This Internet refers to mothers of young children.
n. Send+point+problem. Very easy question [on an exam]. This Internet slang term refers to question to which you must know the answer.

n. Send+life+problem. Dangerous question that could get you killed if you didn’t answer it correctly. This Internet slang term refers to a tricky question raised by someone who expects you to answer it exactly the way he or she wants.

column2: bù kě miáo shù zhī shì
column3: n. The indescribable thing. Sex.

<Expression> Mouth+avoid+body+honest. They say they don’t want it, but their body language says otherwise. Short for the Japanese expression “口が嫌だと言っても体は正直なものだ,” this expression pokes fun at people who deny their true feelings about something. It is often used in a romantic or sexual context, referring to someone who claimed to dislike a date or crush, but their bodily reactions suggest otherwise.

column1: 嘴上说不要，身体却很诚实
column2: zuǐ shàng shuō bú yào, shēn tǐ què hěn zhèng zhí
column3: <Expression> Another translation of 口嫌體正直 [kǒu xián tǐ zhèng zhí]: Orally [they] say they don’t want it, but [their] bodies are very honest.

<Expression> To flee from Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou. This expression describe the phenomenon of white-collar workers quitting their jobs in China’s metropolises, especially Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou, and choose to work and live in second- and third-tier cities instead. They give up the life in first-tier cities often because they can’t afford the apartment prices or bear the air pollution in those metropolises.

n. Bass, any of various North American freshwater fish with lean flesh (especially of the genus Micropterus). This Internet slang term is a derogatory nickname for Chinese talk show host Chen Luyu because of similar pronunciation. Sexism is evident in the use of this term.

adj. rustic+excited. This Internet slang term was originally used to describe an electronic dance music dilettante who mistakes DJ for electronic dance music. Now it is commonly used to describe Chinese electronic dance music that sound amateurish by international standards. The contempt for unsophisticated composers is quite obvious, judged from the use of the character 土 [tǔ] “uncouth, unsophisticated, rural.”

<Expression> Brain+Watt. The brain is damaged. 瓦特 [wǎ tè] means “damaged” in the Shanghai dialect. This expression is used to lambaste someone. The meaning is similar to “[someone] is going nuts” or “[someone] is stupid.”
n. Boast+criminal. Blowhard, barggart, poseur.
n./v. Region+cannon. To berate people from a region on the Internet.
<Expression> Get excited. Quoted from the song “Miss Dong” by Song Dongye, this expression is used to encourage people to become excited about something.

column1: 好看的皮囊千篇一律，有趣的灵魂万里挑一
column2: hǎo kàn de pí náng qiān piān yí lǜ, yǒu qù de líng hún wàn lǐ tiāo yī
column3: <Expression> Good-looking letter bags all look alike, but interesting souls are one in ten thousand. Good-looking people are similar, but interesting souls are hard to find. This expression is commonly used among fans to describe their idols.
n. Cannon+Boss. This Internet slang term is a nickname for British actor Paul Bettany 炮 [pào] sounds like “Paul.”

n. Old+White. This Internet slang term is a nickname for American actor Bryan Cranston, because 白 [bái] “White” is his last name on Breaking Bad. He gained popularity in China because of his performance on Breaking Bad.
<Expression> It can be said that [very adj. ].  You can say it’s [very adj.]This expression became popular in 2017 to express one’s opinion about something or someone.

Internet addiction+teenage girl. Teenage girl with an addiction to the Internet. This Internet slang term is often used to describe young women who spend way too much time on the Internet, usually because they like watching TV shows or playing mobile games.

column2: wǒ xià miàn gěi nǐ chī
column3: <Expression> I will cook some noodles for you to eat. The expression was originally a classic line in Hong Kong TV shows, but in Simplified Chinese, 下面 [xià miàn] “below, down there” and 下麵 [xià miàn] “cook noodles” are both written as the former word, so mainland Internet users have developed a new interpretation of the line: I will let you eat me down there.
n. Dirty+braids. Deadlocks.
n. On the bed+exercise. Exercise in bed. This Internet slang term is a euphemism for sexual intercourse.

v. Foolish+cry. (Of behavior) so asinine that it brought me to tears. This Internet slang term is a common quibble about something and someone that does not live up to one’s expectation. Hyperbole is involved in this usage.

n. Web+sense. The level of interactivity with the viewers on the Internet. This Internet slang term is often used as a standard for evaluating TV shows. A TV program with a good web sense has a large fan base on the Internet, satisfies Internet users’ aesthetic needs, and sparks heated discussions on the Internet.

adj./n. Kill+horse+special. Smart. The scene people. This Internet slang term mimics the pronunciation of the English word “smart,” but it is used to tease the teenagers and young adults who prefer a fashion style that emphasizes androgyny and bright colors. These young people usually migrated from rural areas to urban areas. They lack higher education and take on low-income jobs in cities. Their fashion choices reflect their need for attention and sense of alienation in the process of urbanization.
n. Wash+cut+blow. This Internet slang term refers to the scene people’s hairstyle as well the scene people as a group.

column2: dà jí dà lì, jīn wǎn chī jī
column3: <Expression> Great luck, great profit; eat chicken tonight. Winner winner, chicken dinner. This expression is from the popular mobile game “Player Unknown’s Battlegrounds.” Now the second part of the slogan has become another way of saying “I have a nice plan for tonight.”

n. High-end face. This Internet slang term refers to the latest beauty trend among Chinese women. A Chinese woman who has a high-end face usually looks a little masculine. She often has the single eyelids, relatively small, long, and wide-set eyes, slightly higher cheekbones, thicker lips, and a chiseled jawline. The above facial features convey an air of aloofness and even frigidity. This trend differs from the traditional standard for female beauty which accentuates femininity and childlike innocence. The Chinese models popular in the West such as Lv Yan, Du Juan, and Liu Wen may have contributed to popularity of this Internet slang term.
n. Male+channel. Internet novels that target male readers. Such novels are usually about wars and picking up women.
n. Female+channel. Internet novels that target female readers. Such novels are usually about love triangles and homosexual love.

v. Repair+document. To re-upload a shared file to the Internet after a previously created link expired. This Internet slang term is often used in the context of sharing movies or videos on the Internet.
n. No. X shot. Derived from the Japanese culture, this Internet slang term is used to introduce a new piece of work (article, illustration, video) in a series.
n. Fruit+fan. Apple fan. This Internet slang term refers to a fan of Apple products.

n. Spare tire. Back burner. This Internet slang term refers to  a person to whom one is not presently committed, and with whom one maintains some degree of communication, in order to keep or establish the possibility of future romantic and/or sexual involvement.

column2: zhōu dōng yǔ shì níng shì
column3: <Expression> Zhou Dongyu’s gaze. This expression teases actress Zhou Dongyu’s relatively large distance between the eyes.
n. Green light. This Internet slang terms comes from Stephanie Sun’s song “Green Light” but is now used to mock people whom were cheated on by their partners.

column2: tóu dǐng yí piàn cǎo yuán
column3: <Expression> Carry a tract of grassland on one’s head. This expression is used to describe people whose partners cheat on them multiple times..
n. Island nation. This Internet slang term refers to Japan.
<Expression> Surf the web scientifically. This expression is a euphemism for accessing the blocked non-Chinese websites using VPNs. A synonym is 翻墻 [fān qiáng].

<Expression> Brain+loops+refreshing+magical. The unique brain circuits. This expression praises people who think creatively or differently from the majority of the people. Sometimes the expression is used sarcastically.
v. Flip+red. To become popular again. This Internet slang term is often used to describe the public’s renewed interest in celebrity has-beens.
adj. Walk+kidney. Going through the kidney. Adapted from 走心 [zǒu xīn], this Internet slang term refers to something that causes sexual arousal.

n. Buddhist+sect+chase+stars. The Buddhist fandom. This Internet slang term refers to supporting a celebrity in a calm and peaceful way. A Buddhist fan does not engage in online battles against the fans of other celebrities. He or she is not too emotionally invested in the idol either.
n. Buddhist+sect+youth. The Buddhist youth. This Internet slang term is often used to describe the Post-’90 who are less ambitious in life.
n. Buddhist+sect+gamer. The Buddhist gamer. This Internet slang term refers to gamers who don’t care about their game results.
n. Buddhist+sect+breakup. The Buddhist breakup. This Internet term refers to the painless and peaceful breakup. The couple do not experience nervous breakdowns or hostile retribution.

n. Buddhist+sect. The Buddhist style. This Internet slang term describes the detached and often passive attitude towards life. Sometimes it is used positively to describe a placid demeanor like a Buddhist sage.

column2: shè huì zhǔ yì jù yīng
column3: n. Socialist+gigantic+baby. The gigantic socialist baby. This Internet slang term pokes fun at Chinese adults who are not well-differentiated according the Murray Bowen’s Family Systems Theory. They often submit to authority figures. They are narcissistic, controlling, insecure, anxious, vulnerable, irritable, and depressed. It is possibly the Chinese equivalent of “Generation Snowflake.”
n. Peacock. This Internet slang term is Chinese fans’ nickname for the American actor Matt Bomer.

column2: yù jiàn gèng hǎo de zì jǐ
column3: Meet the better self. This expression is a popular slogan to encourage self-improvement.
n. Solid+hammer. Irrefutable evidence. This Internet slang term is often used negatively to describe the confirmed scandal.
. Beg+hammer+get+hammer. This expression means “if you ask for a hammer [evidence], you will get a hammer [evidence].” It is often used before revealing the irrefutable evidence for a rumor.
n. Beside+friend. Friend. This Internet slang term is a phonetic deviation of 朋友 [péng yǒu] “friend” and 胖友 [pàng yǒu] “fat friend.”
n. Fat+friend. Friend. This Internet slang term is a phonetic deviation of 朋友 [péng yǒu] “friend.”
v. To tear [the vagina]. Derived from 撕逼 [sī bī] “to have verbal fights online,” This Internet slang term means “to inveigh against [someone].”
n. Rice+Uncle. Uncle Mi. This Internet slang term is an affectionate nickname for Indian artist Aamir Khan.
n. Widow+Sister. Sister [Black] Widow. This Internet slang term is a nickname for American actress Scarlett Johansson.
adj. Unsophisticated+fat+round. This derogatory Internet slang term is often used in body shaming and self-mockery.

v. Randon+enter. Derived from the Japanese phrase  “乱入 らんにゅう”, this Internet slang term refers to an unexpected appearance that is often hilarious. It is often used to describe an interruption in a presentation or conversation.
n. Chestnut. Example. This Internet slang term is a funny way of saying 例子 [lì zi] “example” because they are homophones.
v. Compete+pictures. To bicker or joke using pictures. This Internet slang term refers to having a playful pictorial conversation online.
n. Mother+Her Excellency. Derived from the Japanese honorific title ” haha-ue” (ははうえ), this Internet slang term is used humorously to address one’s mother.
n. Father+His Majesty. Derived from the Japanese honorific title “chichi-ue”  (ちちうえ) ,  this Internet slang term is used humorously to address one’s father.

column1: 做一个精致的猪猪女孩
column2: zuǒ yí gè jīng zhì de zhū zhū nǚ hái
column3: <Expression> Be a refined piggy girl. This expression scoffs at fangirls who like staying in and binge-watching videos featuring their idols. “Piggy” refers to their physical appearance and lifestyle. Due to the sedentary lifestyle, they are often believed to be overweight. The stereotype is undoubtedly pejorative and hurtful.

<Expression> The ovarian lottery. This expression is quoted from Warren Buffet who attributed his success to winning the “ovarian lottery.” In China, this Internet slang term is used to lament one’s misfortune of not being born with a silver spoon in his or her mouth.

n. [Fish] pond owner. This Internet slang term is a pejorative nickname for Zhang Han, because his famous line in the TV show Boss & Me:  “I want to let everyone know: This fish pond, is now under your management by contract.” People jeer his role for making a ludicrous confession of love by mentioning a fish pond. The nickname implies discrimination against country people and contempt for Zhang Han.
n. Push+special. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Twitter.

n. Fellow Taoist priests. This Internet slang term is used humorously to describe people who share your hobbies or values. It is also a euphemism for drug users, because of the stereotype that they are so pale and gaunt that they look like Taoist priests who are believed to become immortals.

column2: wǒ kě néng v. de shì jiǎ n.
column3: <Expression> I+probably+v+a fake+n.. This sentence structure is often used to quip about something unexpected.

adj. Oily, greasy. This Internet slang term was made popular by Chinese writer Feng Tang in his article “How to Avoid Becoming a Greasy, Creepy Middle-Aged Man.” The article reminds middle-aged Chinese men not to: get fat, stop learning, stay still, talk about sex in public, be overtly nostalgic, lecture youngsters, cause trouble for others, stop shopping, ignore personal hygiene and grooming, or despise healthy life habits. In that sense, “greasy” describes a person who is indolent, narcissistic, annoying, misogynistic, and/or lewd.

column2: fěn sī xíng wéi, ǒu xiàng mǎi dān
column3: <Expression> Fans’ behavior+the idol pays the bill. This expression means “the idol pays the price for the fans’ inappropriate behavior.” This caveat reminds the fans to conduct themselves online and offline so their idol’s reputation won’t be tarnished.

v. Open+black. <Gaming Terminology> To have audio chats or even face-to-face communication with the other players to have an edge on the opponents in a computer game. The behavior may enhance cooperation and increase the possibility of cheating as well.
<Expression> Visual estimate+will go viral. By visual estimate, this will go viral. This expression is often used humorously to discuss how likely something will cause a stir on the Internet.

v. To plant a flag. <Gaming terminology> (Of a code segment) to foreshadow the development of an event. As an Internet slang term. it means to make a statement only to find out it is wrong or to make a promise only to break it later. It also means to set a goal that may or may not be reached.
n. The white haired girl. This Internet slang term is a humorous moniker for Starbucks. The White Haired Girl is one of the earliest PRC films.
n. The Kaifeng cuisine. This Internet slang term is a humorous moniker for KFC, because they share the acronym.
n. The golden arched door. This Internet slang term is the new official Chinese name of McDonald’s.
<Expression> The Qing dynasty has already perished. This expression is often used to criticize outmoded ways of thinking and behaving, such as authoritarianism and misogyny.

column2: zhè shèng shì rú nǐ suǒ yuàn
column3: <Expression> This golden age, as you wished for. This expression is often used sarcastically to express discontent with government misconduct.
v. To hang someone up and beat him or her. To lash out on someone.
n. Model worker+ sister. Sister model worker. This Internet slang term is an affectionate nickname for Jessica Chastain to show the fans’ admiration for her productivity and the quality of her works.

adj. Womb+Solo [performance]. (Of a person) single since birth. Derived from the Korean phrase “모태솔로”, this Internet slang term pokes fun at people who have never been in a relationship so that their lives are like solo performances. It is the latest alternative of 單身狗 [dān shēn gǒu] “single dog.”
interj. An enthusiastic way of showing confirmation.

column1: 我能怎么办? 我也很绝望啊!
column2: wǒ néng zěn me bàn? wǒ yě hěn jué wàng a
column3: <Expression> What can I do? I am also in despair. This expression is used humorously to express how shocked and helpless one feels. It is often used humorously.

n. Kumamon, a mascot created by the government of Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan in 2010 for a campaign to draw tourists to the region. A number of emojis have been circulated on China’s Internet based on the image of Kumamon.
v. Sniff+smog. To have to sniff smog constantly because of air pollution. This Internet slang term mimics the word 吸煙 [xī yān] “smoking.”

v. Sniff+cat. (Of a cat owner) to sniff the cat. This Internet slang term is often used by cat owners to describe their love for cats. They can’t help hugging and playing with the cats as soon as they see them, and they even like sniffing the smell of cats. The term mimics the word 吸煙 [xī yān] “smoking.”

adj./n. Shake+S. Seriously sadistic. A seriously sadistic person. Derived from the Japanese wordドS in the ACG subculture, this Internet slang term refers to the tendency to derive pleasure, especially sexual gratification, from inflicting pain, suffering, or humiliation on others.

adj./n. Shake+M. Seriously masochistic. A seriously masochistic person. Derived from the Japanese wordドM in the ACG subculture, this Internet slang term refers to the tendency to derive sexual gratification from one’s own pain or humiliation.
v. Strongly+stand [behind you]. To strongly agree with [you]. To strongly support [you].

n. Inability to love. This Internet slang term refers to some people’s inability to enter a relationship. The reasons vary. Some people are traumatized by past relationships, some are too narcissistic to love others, some are afraid of commitment, some repress their feelings too much…Some people attribute their singledom to their inability to love.
v. Unlock+skill. To pick up a new skill.

n. Black+flower. Hey Wow. This Internet slang term is the name of Wallace Chung’s stuffed panda doll aka his “daughter.” Wallace Chung later developed spin-offs like caps, shoes, dolls, backpacks, etc. based on the image of Hey Wow.
n. Black+grass. This Internet slang term refers to Wallace Chung’s male fans.

v. Lead+rhythm. <Gaming terminology> To instigate a fight. This Internet slang term is originally used to describe a gamer who determines the strategies for the whole team in a group video or computer game. Now it is used to describe an Internet user who misleads others with wrong information or offensive language in online discussions and instigates verbal fights among groups holding opposing views.

n. Photo+deception. [Inaccurate] photo. This Internet slang term refers to a photo that does not truthfully reflect a person’s appearance. It is usually over-photoshopped. This term and 照片 [zhào piàn/pian] are homophones.

n. <Fandom Terminology> Pig spirit+girl. This sexist Internet slang term originally referred to female fans who eat a lot like pigs and feel so good about themselves and therefore are annoying to others. Now it also refers to fat, ugly women with a histrionic personality. Sometimes it is used for self-mockery.

<Expression> Defy heaven and change one’s destiny. This expression comes from the TV series Fighter of the Destiny. The protagonist Chen Changsheng is plagued with an incurable illness, fated not to live past the age of twenty. He is therefore determined to find the magic stone that will change his fate.
v. Cut. This Internet slang term is widely used on The Encyclopedia of Awkwardness, a Chinese humor website, to indicate the transition from background information to the main part of the joke.
<Expression> Shake+cleverness. Make a wisecrack. This expression is used slightly negatively to describe people who quip to show off how witty they are.
n. Broken eyebrow. This Internet slang term is an affectionate nickname for Charlie Puth.
n. Awkward+Snow. This Internet slang term is an affectionate nickname for Jon Snow, a character in Game of Thrones, because of 囧 [jiǒng] sounds like “Jon.”
<Expletive>This is a sexist expletive phrase from the Chongqing dialect. It means “Your mom is a prostitute.” The alternatives are mmp [pinyin acronym] and X賣批 [mā mài pī].
n. & adj. An effeminate man. Dander. This Internet slang term is a sexist term to describe metrosexuals and men with feminine qualities.
v. Group+mock. (Of a group of people) to laugh at someone.
n. E+deity. A nickname for Eason Chan, a Hong Kong singer, because it sounds like “Eason.”
<Expression> [One of Xue Zhiqian’s pet phrases] Neurotic! This expression means “Are you crazy?” or “Are you nuts?”.

column2: wǒ bú yào miàn zi de a
column3: [One of Xue Zhiqian’s pet phrases] [You think] I don’t want face?! This expression means “You think I don’t want a good reputation?”.
[One of Xue Zhiqian’s pet phrases] The whole segment collapses. This expression means “Epic fail!”

n. High+imitate+account. Weibo accounts that pretend to be owned by celebrities in order to attract followers. Such accounts often steal celebrities’ pictures and imitate their writing styles. Oversharing is another common weakness among those fake accounts. When an celebrity posts weibos too often or displays qualities that are little known to the public on Weibo, their fans will also quip that those celebrities’ weibo accounts are fakes.

<Expression> Swag+side leakage [as of sanitary towels]. This expression humorously describes a person’s excessive domineering presence or pompous display of expertise or fortune that makes people around him or her slightly uncomfortable.
adj. Incisive. This Internet slang term is often used to describe a piercing glance, a sharp-witted person, or an accurate and cutting remark.
n. Brother Incisive. A homeless man called Cheng Guorong who was dubbed “Brother Incisive” on China’s Internet in 2010 for his piercing gaze and outlandish outfits.
<Expression> Allow oneself to take off. This Internet slang term is used humorously to describe someone who behaves with careless abandon. It can be either positive or negative.
<Expression> [Of news, etc. ] so thrilling that everyone is rejoicing and spreading the word. This expression is an acronym combining the first characters of four idioms:
Love to see and hear.
[usually of the punishment of an evil-doer] Most gratifying to the people.
The whole world or nation rejoices.
Run around spreading the news.
v. & n. Surround+smile. Smile. This Internet slang term, an alternative of 微笑 [wēi xiào] “smile” because they sound alike, mimics the Taiwanese Mandarin accent.
n. Drama+spirit. An attention-seeking person with a histrionic display of emotions and/or opinions. This Internet slang term is sometimes used humorously.

<Expression> Appearance is justice. This expression is used to humorously defend one’s preference for nice-looking people, to the dismay of plain-looking people and those who are against body shaming. The expression is sometimes used sarcastically.

column2: pí pí xiā, wǒ men zǒu
column3: <Expression> Mantis shrimp, let’s go. This expression is used humorously to show discontent and threaten to exit the online conversation.

v. To lock the auditorium. This Internet slang term describes the phenomenon that ardent fans purchase one to two movie tickets for each movie auditorium where their idols’ movie is scheduled to be screened, in order to give theatrical exhibitors the false impression that their idols’ movies are very popular so that the movie would be screened at more movie theaters.

<Expression> Bomb me out. This expression is often used in sentences like “this question/word/picture bombed me out” meaning that the question/word/picture evokes one’s desire to speak up on the Internet.
n. Sentiment. This Internet slang term is used to describe one’s passion about something bigger than oneself. Sometimes it is used sarcastically.
<Expression> Do not forget the original aspiration. This expression is used to remind oneself or to commend others for sticking to one’s beliefs or dreams.

adj./v. To vegetate due to deep frustration. This Internet slang became popular in 2016 following Internet memes like 葛優癱 [gě yōu tān] “the Ge You slouch”, 廢柴 [fèi chái] “trashy firewood, douchebags”, 生無所戀 [shēng wú suǒ liàn] “There is nothing in life to long for”, Pepe the Frog, etc. Analysts attribute the popularity of this Internet slang term to the post-90s‘ [people born between 1990 and 1999] pessimism about social mobility amidst a host of social problems such as air pollution, the skyrocketing housing prices, and workplace stress.

n. The subculture of vegetating. This Internet slang term refers to a collection of beliefs and behaviors that enable the working-class youth in China to express their pessimism about life and their future.

n. Little+definite+frustration. A sarcastic antonym of 小确幸 [xiǎo què xìng] “Little definite happiness,” this Internet slang term was originally the title of an Internet pop song. Now it is used to describe the working-class youth’s certainty about daily nuisances and the drudgery of work.

v. To root for [someone or something]. This Internet slang term originated from Wotagei or otagei, which refers to a type of dancing and cheering gestures performed by wota, fans of Japanese idol singers (and thus seen as Akiba-kei), involving jumping, clapping, arm-waving and chanting slogans.
n. Female driver. This Internet slang term indicates the prejudice that female drivers have poor driving skills.
n. Road+killer. This Internet slang term refers to poor drivers. Female drivers are often unfairly labeled as road killers.

<Expression> It smarts, buddy. This expression is adapted from the Northeastern Chinese dialect. 紮心 [zhā xīn] means “pierce my heart” while 老鐵 [lǎo tiě] is a slang term for “good friend.” This expression became popular at the beginning of 2017 and is often used humorously.
adj. Hand+lacking. This Internet slang term is used to blame oneself or others for clicking on a link that is regrettable, such as seeing or buying something regrettable online.
v. Embarrassment+chat. To have an awkward and hilarious conversation usually because the people don’t see eye to eye.

n. Little+nymph. 小姐姐 [xiǎo jiě jiě] n. Little+older sister. Both Internet slang terms are used to address or describe girls and young women. These two newly-coined terms have probably rendered 美眉/MM [měi méi] “pretty girl” obsolete…[允悲]

column2: hái yǒu zhè zhǒng cāo zuò
column3: <Gaming terminology> Expression. This gambit exists?! An equivalent of “Didn’t see this coming.” This expression recently replaced 黑人問號 [hēi rén wèn hào] to express one’s confusion, amazement, or shock.

n. Black person+question marks. This Internet slang term derives from pictures of Nicholas Aaron “Nick” Young, an NBA player for the Los Angeles Lakers, with question marks added. This meme is used when you are perplexed, shocked, or speechless.
v. Stand+queue. To take sides.
Smash+resumes. Expression. Smash [us with your] resumes. This Internet slang term is used by employers on social media to invite job applicants to email resumes to them.
v. Push+send. Recommend+send [articles]. This Internet slang term is widely by organizations on Weibo and WeChat to notify the subscribers or followers of the latest articles.
n. Green green. This Internet slang term refers to the Muslims, because green is an important color in the Muslim world.

v. To climb over a wall. This Internet slang term means to climb over the Great Firewall of China, a censorship and surveillance project that blocks potentially unfavorable incoming data from foreign countries. The purpose is to access blocked overseas websites.
adj. On this side of the wall. This Internet slang term refers to the Internet environment affected by the Great Firewall.
adj. On the other side of the wall. This Internet slang term refers to the Internet environment unaffected by the Great Firewall.
v. Abuse+abdomen. To do intense ab workouts, especially to develop a visible Adonis belt or a V-shaped core.

column1: 爱笑的女孩运气不会太差
column2: ài xiào de nǚ hái yùn qi bú huì tài chà
column3: : Girls who like laughing usually don’t have bad luck.
v. To pour dog food. (Of a couple) to show affection toward each other online or offline, which may trigger envy, jealousy, and self-pity among single people.

n. Memory+kill. In the Japanese comic book series Naruto, killing scenes tend to begin with flashbacks of incidents from the past. As an Internet slang term, it refers to the emotional reminiscing about the past.

n. Gently caress and stroke the head+kill. Originating from the Japanese manga trope of a guy caressing a gloomy girl’s head to comfort her, this Internet slang term is now regarded as a favorable flirting or titillating technique (effective only when used by one’s love interest or idol).

n. Teen girl’s heart. A person with a teen girl’s heart is girly, dreamy, sensitive, vigorous, and sentimental. This Internet slang term is often used positively to describe a person who unapologetically adores girly toys and longs for romantic chance encounters with male celebrities like a moony teenage fangirl. This term sometimes runs the risk of perpetuating gender stereotypes about girls and teenagers.

n. Three-year-old. This Internet slang term is often coupled with someone’s last name. It became popular first when used to describe Hong Kong actor Francis Ng aka Wu Zhenyu when he appeared with his son on the reality TV show Where Are We Going, Dad in 2014. Netizens dubbed him “Wu Three-Year-Old”, amused by his mischievous and childlike personality on the show as well as on Weibo. The meme has been widely used to describe many beloved celebrities.
n. Labor+capital. I.. This Internet slang term means 老子 [lǎo zi] “I (used jocularly and arrogantly)” because they sound similar.

n. To lacerate the devils [a term of abuse for foreign invaders, particularly Japanese invaders] by hand. This Internet slang term pokes fun at the 2011 Chinese TV drama The Curious Maestros against Japanese Invasion in which a Kungfu master tears up the Japanese invaders in the War of Resistance against Japan (1937-1945). The plot was berated online and by state-run newspapers like People’s Daily for distorting history.

n. Epic dramas of the War of Resistance against Japan. This Internet slang term mocks TV dramas that blend history with fantasy to over-glorify the Chinese army in the War of Resistance against Japan. Such dramas are widely criticized by both the media and Internet users for distorting history.
v. To reply within a second. To reply promptly.

adj. Heart+big. This Internet slang term describes people who are so careless that they may put themselves or others in danger. It also describes people who are less susceptible to criticism or personal attacks because they don’t give a damn.
adj. Big-faced. This Internet slang term is used to criticize someone for being brazen or narcissistic.
v. To make self-effacing comments. It could be a form of humble brag, but it could also serve the sole purpose of amusing others.

column2: nǐ de liáng xīn bú huì tòng ma
column3: <Expression> Doesn’t your conscience feel pain? This expression originated from an Internet joke about the bromance between Tang poets Du Fu and Li Bai. The joke claims that Du Fu wrote 12 poems for or about Li Bai, but Li Bai reciprocated with only one poem. The joke writer felt sorry for the “mistreated” Du Fu and questioned Li Bai if he felt guilty for his “cruelty” with the aforementioned expression. Regardless of its original interrogative tone, this expression is now often used humorously to tease someone.
n. Traffic+young man.
n. Traffic+little flower.
n. Bonsai+elf/spirit. This Internet slang term is a loving nickname for The Weeknd due to his dreadlocks resembling a bonsai tree.

n. Ge You slouch. This Internet slang term referring to the sitting posture of actor Ge You’s role in the classic sitcom I Love My Family (1993-1994). It became popular in summer 2016 to describe how people relax in the sweltering heat.

Expression. Don’t talk, kiss me. This expression was a caption of pouting selfies flaunted by a successful gamer. It also appeared in the lyrics of an internet pop song. Now it is used for joking or playing cute.
<Expression> An alternative way of 厲害了我的… [lì hài le wǒ de…]. This expression substitutes 我的… [wǒ de…] “my…”with “word”… because of similar pronunciations.
n. Click+like+acquaintances. People who maintain a minimal connection or their friendship superficially by liking each other’s social media posts.
Particle. This Internet slang term is a substitute for 了 [le] which is a particle indicating the completion of an action. It also mimics the Taiwanese Mandarin accent.

column2: zhè yàng de…gěi wǒ lái yì dá
column3: <Expression> Give me a dozen of…like this. This expression is used to emphasize one’s affection for something or someone.

column2: guǐ zhī dào wǒ jīng lì le shén me
column3: <Expression> The ghost knows what I went through. God knows what I went through. This expression was first made popular by swimmer Fu Yuanhui during the 2016 Rio Olympics when she described her challenging training experiences. She used another Internet slang term 洪荒之力 [hóng huāng zhī lì] “preternatural power” in the interview. Her candid and humorous replies made her an Internet sensation.

column2: shén me chóu, shén me yuàn
column3: <Expression> What grudge do you hold against me? This expression first became popular in 2014 as a passenger’s reply to another passenger who tried to stop him from cracking melon seeds on the bus. They kept arguing for seven minutes while the melon seed cracker grumbled “What grudge do you hold against me [so that you keep pestering me]?” several times during the process. Now the expression is used as a comment on or complaint about an interpersonal conflict that one does not fully understand.
n. Trashy+firewood. Loser. Schmuck. This Internet slang term describes a loser or worthless person who has the potential to be rich and realize his or her dreams one day.
n. Black+history. One’s disgraceful past. Sometimes it is used humorously to describe one’s embarrassing experiences when he or she was a rookie.
n. Money+lass. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Kesha.

n. Jimmy+fat+[Fal]lon+show. This Internet slang term is a chirpy translation of The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon. However, 肥倫 [féi lún] “Fatlon” is used only because it sounds similar with “Fallon” but it is not a nickname for the host himself. The alternative translations include 肥倫秀 [féi lún xiù] “Fatlon Show” and 吉米肥倫今夜秀 [jí mǐ féi lún jīn yè xiù] “Jimmy Fatlon Tonight Show.”

n. Jimmy+Chicken feather+show. This Internet slang term is a chirpy translation of Jimmy Kimmel Live! because 雞毛 [jī máo] “chicken feather” sounds like “Kimmel.” However, 雞毛 [jī máo] “chicken feather” is a not a nickname for Jimmy Kimmel. A shorter translation of the show name is 雞毛秀 [jī máo xiù] “Chicken Feather Show.”
n. Button+button+bear. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Stephen Colbert because it sounds like his last name “Colbert.”
n. Awkward+Situ [Chinese surname]. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Jon Stewart due to similar pronunciation.
n. Rain God. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Jam Hsiao or Xiao Jingteng because his presence in new cities during the concert tour tended to coincide with downpours.
n. Fruit+sister. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Katy Perry because of her colorful wardrobe. She is also famous for the fruity outfit in the Super Bowl halftime performance.

column2: fù lán lán / fǔ lán lán
column3: n. Fu Lanlan or Rotten Lanlan.. This Internet slang term is an affectionate nickname for James Franco because it sounds like his last name. “Lanlan” is traditionally a female name and 腐 [fǔ] as an Internet slang term means “obsessed with bromance or romance between two young men .”
n. Spicy+chick. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Nicki Minaj because it sounds like her last name “Minaj” and compliments her voluptuous figure.
n. Brother Mars. This Internet slang term is an affectionate nickname for Bruno Mars.
n. Tremble+forest. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Tom Hiddleston because it sounds a little like his last name “Hiddleston.”

n. Egg+lass. This Internet slang term is a nickname for the hunky Daniel Wu Yin-cho or Wu Yanzu. The slang term sounds like a nickname for a country girl in North China but it is adapted from the pronunciation of his English name “Daniel.”
n. Curly+Holmes. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Benedict Cumberbatch because of his curly hair and his character Sherlock Holmes.
n. Awkward+[Jo]seph. This Internet slang term is an affectionate nickname for Joseph Leonard Gordon-Levitt, because his facial features look like the Chinese Internet slang term 囧 [jiǒng] “awkward.”
n. Mercury+retrograde. In astrology, when Mercury retrogrades, things tend to go wrong. This Internet slang term is used humorously to describe the reason for mishaps.
n. Mold Mold or Bummed Bummed. This Internet slang term is a loving nickname for Taylor Swift. Her Chinese fans feel sorry for her because her hits used to peak at No.2 on the Billboard Hot 100.
n. Dick+fxxk. This Internet slang term is a derogatory nickname for Justin Biber because the two Chinese characters look like his initials JB which is the Pinyin acronym for 雞巴 [jī bā] “penis.”
n. Commander Gao. This Internet slang term is a nickname for Ryan Gosling because it sounds like the Chinese translation of his last name: 高斯林 [gāo sī lín].

n. Universe+view. Adapted from the word “worldview,” this Internet slang term is often used as a precept reminding people not to take themselves too seriously: Look at yourself from the perspective of the universe, and you’ll realize how trivial your problems are.
Expression. How to+break. How can we solve [a problem]? How should I deal with [a situation]? This expression is used to play cute and provide/ask for a solution.
adj. Frenzied and perverse. As an Internet slang term, it is often used positively or neutrally to describe one’s wildly unexpected behavior.

n. Convey+door. Door-shaped teleporter.【Computing】Portal, the link to a website. This Internet slang term often precedes a website link. It is also often used to request the link to more information on a subject.

v./n. To have one’s open palms face upwards. Smugshrug. This Internet slang term originally described the emoticon ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ and is now often used directly to show that you don’t give a damn about something or have to accept an unfavorable situation.
n. Peripheral [products. ] Merchandise produced to take advantage of a related work or a celebrity featured in the work. A tie-in or spin-off.

n. Black technology. This term first appeared in フルメタル・パニックor Full Metal Panic!, a series of light novels written by Shoji Gatoh and illustrated by Shiki Douji, and referred to technology that is far more advanced than those of the real world. As a Chinese Internet slang term, it describes awe-inspiring technology that is beyond the understanding of the average people. Sometimes this term is used sarcastically.
n. 【Music】Hot+single. Short for 熱門單曲 [rè mén dān qǔ] “hit single.”  This Internet slang term usually refers to European and American pop songs in English.

column1: 你还记得大明湖畔的。。。吗
column2: nǐ hái jì dé dà míng hú pàn de…ma
column3: <Expression> Do you still remember…by the Daming Lake? This question was originally a line from the 1998 TV show Princess Return Pearl [or My Fair Princess]. Ziwei confronted her birth father Emperor Qianlong, “Do you still remember Xia Yuhe by the Daming Lake?” Xia Yuhe is Ziwei’s mother and Ziwei was born out of wedlock. Now this line is used humorously to remind the listener or reader of something or someone.
adj./adv. Off the charts, extrodinarily out of the norm, top of the line. 顏值爆表 [yán zhí bào biǎo] <Expression> To max out the cute-o-meter. Off-the-charts cute/pretty.
adj. Textbook. Meeting the standards set by authorities or experts in the field. 教科書般的吻戏 [jiào kē shū bān de wěn xì] Textbook kissing scenes. Amazing kissing scenes.

column1: 不装逼我们还是好朋友
column2: bù zhuāng bī wǒ men hái shì hǎo péng yǒu
column3: <Expression> If you don’t act all snotty, we can still be good friends.
v. To become mentally remote, to space out; to empty one’s mind.
v. To push [someone] into a pit. To persuade someone to become a fan of novels or manga delivered in serial form.
v. To abandon a pit. To stop posting new chapters of an Internet novel and leave it unfinished; to stop playing an online game; to give up a hobby because of boredom.
v. To get out of a pit. To complete an Internet novel; to accomplish all the tasks in an online game.
v. To fill a pit. To update an online novel.
v. To dig a pit. To start writing an Internet novel and publishing it in installments; to start playing an online game. To start a project that attracts people’s attention.
v. Spooked+pee. To be spooked and wet one’s pants.

n. Bogus experts. Although it is short for 公共知識分子 [gōng gòng zhī shí fèn zǐ] “public intellectual,” this coinage is often a pejorative term for rabble-rousers who seek support on social media by appealing to popular desires and prejudices.
n. Abstinent+sect. This Internet slang term describes the nice-looking and refined heterosexual male celebrities whose aloofness and reticence make them look as if they were not interested in sex.

<Expression> Boinked the dog. 我真是日了狗了 [wǒ zhēn shì rì le gǒu le] “I had boinked the dog” is a vulgar way of whining “What have I done to deserve this?” It goes well with a facepalm.The term was originally an ID on Douyu TV (live streaming site).
Expression. Short for 然而並沒有什麽卵用 [rán ér bìng méi yǒu shén me luǎn yòng] “But it is useless” or “But it doesn’t make any difference.” This expression is used to express one’s frustration or contempt.
v. Chase+drama. To binge-watch TV dramas or to keep up with the latest episodes of a new TV series.

v. Visually+rape. This Internet slang term originated in Japan to describe sexual objectification of women in photography, but now in China it means: 1) to stare at women in a lewd way; 2) to annoy others online through oversharing.
