n. Brick+expert. Charlatans. This Internet slang term and 專家 [zhuān jiā] are homophones. It is a cynical nickname for bogus experts who mislead the public with irresponsible or unreliable comments. Their credibility is jeopardized by their own ignorance or depravity.

column2: gān le zhè wǎn dú jī tāng
column3: Drink up this bowl of poisonous chicken soup. To swallow the hard truth. To swallow the bitter pill. This invitation is used before pointing out the poignant reality or harsh-sounding advice and asking the audience to accept it.
n. First+forest. Sir, mister. This Internet slang term is a phonetic deviation of 先生 [xiān shēng] with a southern accent. The use of this slang term indicates playfulness and/or affection.

v. Kneel+lick. To suck up to someone; to treat someone with a servile attitude; to blindly admire someone or something. This Internet slang term also humorously describes one’s fervent admiration for someone or something.
Expression. Meticulously+think+fear+extreme. To think carefully about something to a point where one is petrified to the extreme.

column2: qǐng shōu xià wǒ de xī gài
column3: <Expression> Please accept my knees. Please allow me to kneel down in front of you. Please accept my reverence [for you].
v. To catch a [cute person, animal, or thing] alive. This Internet slang term is often used humorously to describe a happy encounter or discovery online or offline.

v. Cadge+heat. To freeload the popularity of a more famous celebrity for personal gain, especially public attention. This Internet slang term is often used by the fans to attack someone whom they often consider to be less popular than their idol.
n. Single+woof. Single+woof.  This Internet slang term refers to single people who are eager to enter a relationship but find it difficult to achieve the goal.
adj. Hi+P. This Internet slang term is a phonetic deviation of “happy.”
Interj. Zoikes; well, well; oh Lord; wow.

column2: nǐ zhè shì zài gǎo shì qing
column3: Expression. You are causing trouble for me. Actor Chen He frequently used this expression on the Chinese version of Running Man. Now this expression is used to vent or joke about unexpected or undesirable situations.
v. Hold+claw. A cute way of saying 握手 [wò shǒu] “shake hands.”
v. 1. To inveigh against [someone]. 2. To debate with [someone].
<Expression> To love and kill each other. This Internet slang term humorously describes a de facto or assumptive love-hate relationship between two individuals.

column2: nǐ zǎ bú shàng tiān ne
column3: Expression. Why don’t you just go up into the sky? You might say that to a person who is full of hot air or feels too good about himself or herself. Hopefully your sarcasm will bring them down to earth
Expression. Implode right where you are. This expression is used to indicate one’s dissatisfaction with or anger at a person’s statement or action. It is a euphemism for “Get lost.”
adj. Cute+explode. Explosively cute. Cute overload.

column2: lái a, hù xiāng shāng hài a
column3: <Expression> Come on, let’s hurt each other. At first glance, this expression is used to provoke a quarrel, but more often than not, it serves to humorously comment on a potentially combative situation.

<Expression> First+bookmark+later+read. Since 馬 [mǎ]=馬克 [mǎ kè]=Mark=Bookmark, this phrase means “Bookmark it for later perusal.” It is used when you re-share something you like and want to read more closely when you have a moment.

n. Blue+slim+shiitake mushroom. This Internet slang term is how a 24-year-old man from Nanning, Guangxi said 難受想哭 [nán shòu xiǎng kū] “Sad, want to cry” in the Nanning dialect. His teary monologue made him an Internet sensation overnight.

v. Grow+grass. This Internet slang term compares recommending products to others to growing grass, because one plants the seeds of desire for the product in the listener’s mind. The speaker is usually a fashion blogger or a loyal consumer of a brand.

n. Little+white. This Internet slang term is analogous to “rookie” or “newbie.” This term is often used to describe one’s inexperience in a field. It is a neutral or positive term because it implies one’s need for learning.

column2: nán shén jīng / nǚ shén jīng
column3: Male buffoon/ female buffoon.. Slightly different from 男神/女神 [nán shén / nǚ shén] which literally mean “god/goddess,“ this set of Internet slang terms are saved for your goofy friends or yourself. Although 神經 [shén jīng] is short for 神經病 [shén jīng bìng] “neurotic,” many people won’t feel offended. These two Internet slang terms tend to be deemed positive for acknowledging a person’s sense of humor.
v. Literally “flash,” this Internet slang term means to leave swiftly, to beat a hasty retreat.

adj. Poisonous. This Internet slang term is often used to describe any viral Internet meme such as a catchy melody, an Internet spoof, and a humorous emoji, that is addictive. It also describes a person who is goofy and funny.
adj. Stir-fry+chicken. This Internet slang term means 超級 [chāo jí] “super, extremely.” Since the vegetarians and vegans in China don’t eat chicken anymore, they put the dish name to good use…

adj. Strike. This verb as an Internet slang term is a phonetic deviation of 超 [chāo] “super, extremely.” When you use this meme in Internet posting or online conversations, you are deliberately trying to lighten up or act cute.
pron. Mud+cute. You guys. This Internet slang term is a phonetic deviation of 你們 [nǐ men] “you guys.” This term is often used humorously.
n./adj. Holding (hands). This Internet slang term means “lesbian.” Similar terms include 百合 [bǎi hé] lily, 女同 [nǚ tóng] female+same, and 蕾絲邊 [léi sī biān] lace+border.
adj. Having great panache, radiant with confidence, displaying distinctive and stylish elegance. This Internet slang term praises one’s appearance, fashion sense, mannerisms, and/or character.

column2: lì hài le wǒ de gē
column3: <Expression> Wow you rock, my brother. This Internet slang term came into popularity as a high school student’s comment on the dazzling gaming skills of his military training instructor who caught him playing The King’s Glory on the phone. Instead of confiscating the phone, the instructor unleashed his inner gamer and helped the student win the game. This expression is now used to express astonishment or amazement. The word “brother” is replaced in other contexts to address different people.

V. To strike the blackboard with one’s knuckles or hand (to ask the students to pay attention). This Internet slang term is reminiscent of the teaching style of many Chinese teachers. This Internet slang term is used to emphasize something.

column2: cǐ chù yīng yǒu zhǎng shēng
column3: <Expression> A round of applause is expected here. This expression is often humorously used by the self-touted speaker to invite the audience to acknowledge what he or she just said.

column2: gǎn jué shēn tǐ bèi tāo kōng
column3: <Expression> [I] feel the insides of my body were scooped out. I feel so drained. This Internet slang term is used to describe fatigue and depression. For example, you can use it to describe how you feel when your boss incessantly asks you to work overtime.
v. To derail. To suddenly change the subject; to suddenly become distracted.

v. To know, know of. This Internet slang term is a funny variation of 知道 [zhī dào]. They sound similar especially when you say the original word very fast. It was created to mimic the way the word is uttered in Taiwanese Idol TV dramas.

column1: 始于颜值，陷于才华，忠于人品
column2: shǐ yú yán zhí, xiàn yú cái huá, zhōng yú rén pǐn
column3: Expression. [My love for my idol] started because of his or her looks, then I fell for his or her talents, and I stick around because of his or her character.
n. Silly+Ha. Silly husky. This Internet slang term is an affectionate nickname for pet huskies.

n. Infatuated man’s face. This Internet slang term is used to describe one’s ardent admiration for someone or something. It is very often seen in the humorous depiction of one’s adoration for an idol’s looks and/or talents.
n. Wan Wan. This Internet slang term was created by Mainland Internet users as a nickname for Taiwan or the Taiwanese people.

adj./adv. Derived from the original noun “capability,” this Internet slang term is used as an adjective meaning “real,” or “evidence-based” and as an adverb meaning “strongly” and “effectively. ” This term is often used humorously or satirically. For example, 實力裝逼 [shí lì zhuāng bī] v. to try hard to impress others by pretending to be better than one really is. 實力心疼 [shí lì xīn téng] v. To really feel sorry for [someone].

adj. Wall+crack. This Internet slang term and 强烈 [qiáng liè] “strongly” are homophones. This meme is often used to recommend something; the image of a cracked wall is way more vivid than the original word. Imagine someone smacking a wall and speaking effusively.

column2: huò bǐ tè rén (=hā bǐ rén)
column3: n. The Hobbits.. This Internet slang term describes short people in a humorous or affectionate way.

n. Concave+pose=twist+pose.. This Internet slang term refers to striking a 1) trendy and cool, 2) aesthetic but pretentious or unnatural, or 3) funny pose (for photo shooting). This term is often used for humorous effects such as self-mockery.

n. [Role] assumption. This Internet slang term is used after a noun to describe a task or challenge that one takes on. For example, in “Bounty Hunters”, Wallace Chung assumed the role of a jester (喜劇擔當 [xǐ jù dān dāng]), strategist (謀略擔當 [móu luè dān dāng]), and food junkie (吃貨擔當 [chī huò dān dāng]).
n. Mouth+cannon. This Internet slang term refers to telling tall tales or being argumentative and even a little aggressive.
n. Embarrassment+ syndrome.
n. Chagrin+cancer.
n. Laziness cancer. This Internet term is used to describe one’s procrastination or slothfulness.

adj. On+line. Up to scratch. This Internet slang term is a compliment for someone or something that reaches a satisfactory level. For example, you can say an actor’s acting skills are online, meaning his or her acting skills meet the audience’s expectations.
v. Bold+line. To appear, to show up. This Internet slang term and 出現 [chū xiàn] “come up, show up” are homophones. This term is a humorous way of saying “to appear” with a Taiwanese Mandarin accent.
n. Chung+black. Wallace Chung detractors. People who disparage Wallace Chung and his fans.
adv. Again + Again×3 + Again×4. This Internet slang term emphasizes a recurring event.

n. Limpid+stream. A clear stream. This Internet slang term is often used in the context of “XXX is a clear stream in the field of…” to describe a rising star who stands out among others in a field, usually for his or her refreshing candor or sense of humor.
n. Mud-and-stone flow. Mudflow. This Internet slang also refers to someone who stands out in a field for his or her great sense of humor.
v. To eat soil. This Internet slang term quips about the consequence of spending too much money on online shopping—eating nothing but soil because soil is free.
n. Old cadres. An “old cadre” is a male actor whose gravitas in conduct and speech seems a little outdated but is still very adorable for his crazy female fans.
v. To mash [someone]. To defeat someone with an obvious advantage in intelligence, wealth, etc.
n. Literally “sprayers,” this Internet slang term means Internet trolls, or people who make deliberately offensive or provocative online postings.

Gesticulate+heart. Or pencil lead. Make a heart-shape with one’s hand or one’s thumb and index finger to show love and support. There are generally three ways. Click on the Chinese word to see the picture instructions.
n. Taiwanese Internet slang term meaning 呵呵 [hē hē], the sound of a smirk or an adorable giggle. Also, the term recently became the nickname of Chinese table tennis player Zhang Jike.

n. Pretty and coquettish bitches. This Internet slang term was made popular by Taiwanese vlogger @谷阿莫 who is famed for producing video synopses of movies and TV series. In the synopses, the term was used frequently in the sentence “[The male lead] feels [the female lead] is so innocent, so unpretentious, and so different from those pretty coquettish bitches outside.” This term describes the type of women that grosses the male leads out, but of course irony is often involved.

column2: hǎo dān chún hǎo bú zuò zuò
column3: <Expression> So innocent, so unpretentious. This Internet meme was made popular by vlogger @谷阿莫 in his synopses of movies and TV series. This term is usually used to explain the reason why the male lead fell in love with the female lead.

adj. Mystical, inexplicable.. This Internet slang term sounds like “honey+juice” so the latter is often used as an alternative. They are popularly used to point out things that are not obvious or hard to understand, such as dry humor.
n. White lotus flower. 1) Kind, innocent, lovable, good people. 2) People who pretend to be kind, innocent, and lovable.

n. The watermelon-eating people. This Internet slang term is often used in the context of 不明真相的吃瓜群眾 [bù míng zhēn xiàng de chī guā qún zhòng] the watermelon-eating people who are oblivious to the truth. This term was originally used to describe the public whose interest is jeopardized by the civil servants who blindly follow the directions of their injudicious supervisors. Now it describes Internet users who are gossipy and inquisitive or who are awear of certain hot topics but decline to comment on something. They often chalk up their silence or apathy to disinterest or the lack of access to the truth.
n. Obsess+beauty. Japanese litereary term たんび (tanbi) which originally referred to aestheticism but has evolved to be connected with BL-themed works since the 1970s.

n. Japanese term doujin referring to a group of people or friends who share an interest, activity, hobbies, or achievement. In China, this term is often used to describe people who are engaged in fanfiction writing.

column1: 对方不想和你说话并向你扔了一只狗
column2: duì fāng bù xiǎng hé nǐ shuō huà bìng xiàng nǐ rēng le yì zhī gǒu
column3: n. The other party didn’t want to talk to you and threw a dog at you. This Internet slang term went popular in April, 2016 as a reference to the Reject Message notification on WeChat. The dog is an emoticon sent by one party of the chat after rejecting the message. Rejection of WeChat messages is usually caused by dissatisfaction of the other party’s opinions or communication styles. This meme has witnessed a variety of permutations starting with “The other party doesn’t want to talk to you and…”
v. Same+frame. (To be captured) in the same picture. To be seen together in public.
v. Carry+wok. 1) To be made the scapegoat. 2) To bear the blame for someone else’s mistake.
v. Dump+wok. 1) To refuse to be wronged. 2) To shirk responsibility while one is actually responsible.

<Expression> [To do something] because of a word of discord. This expression is used to emphasize the unexpected behavior after having a mild disagreement. Sometimes disagreement is not involved, it is used to describe how someone started doing something out of the blue.
n. Gas pipeline. This Internet slang term is a nickname for YouTube. 油 [yóu] “oil or gas” sounds like “you” while 管 [guǎn] “pipe” is a translation of “tube.”

v. Appointment+cannon. To have casual sex such as one-night stands and other related activity. This Internet slang term is created from a male points of view because it is a combination of 約會 [yuē huì] “to have a date” and 打炮 [dǎ pào] “1) To open fire with artillery, 2) a slang term for having sex [with a prostitute], or 3) to jerk off.”
n. Fan.. The pinyin pronunciation of the Chinese character “rice” looks like the English word “fan”
adj. Fan-made.
adj. Fan-shot. (Of videos) shot by fans.
adj. Destroy+childhood. (Of things) leading to the disillusionment about childhood. This Internet slang term is often used to describe a parody of childhood idols or favorites.
n. Dry+goods. Originated from the old-school robber vernacular referring to valuables, this Internet slang term now refers to valuable information or helpful advice.

column2: xíng zǒu de hé ěr méng
column3: n. The walking hormones. Stud muffins, attractive men.
n. Leftover men. A sexist Internet slang term referring to single men over 30 years old.
n. Leftover women. A sexist Internet slang term referring to single women over 27 years old.
interj. An alternative of 那個 [nà ge] “that one. ” A common filler in Mandarin everyday conversations.
v. Hug+lap. To cling to someone’s laps. To curry favor. To be obsequious and exhibit a fawning attitude.
v. To bestow benefits equally. Do not play favorites. This Internet slang term is used to 1) resist unwanted attention, 2) request equal treatment, or 3) brag about the attention one receives.
v. To swipe. To watch [movies or TV dramas].
v. To popularize science. As an Internet meme, it means to explain details about something to outsiders or nonfans.
v. Dog leash. The Internet term sounds like “go die” in English and serves as an expletive.
v. Face+bump. This Internet slang term is often used to describe celebrity look-alikes.

column2: méi xiǎng dào nǐ shì zhè yàng de…
column3: <Expression> I didn’t know you were such a… Traditionally this sentence structure is used to chastise someone, but as an Internet slang term, it is used to reveal a little-known trait of someone or something for comic effect.
n. Colorful+egg. Video teaser.
n. Turquoise pond. Bitch. This Internet slang term is a euphemism for “bitch” because of the similar pronunciation.

n. The old driver. The Internet slang term started off referring to a person who likes talking dirty. The internet meme comes from “老司機，嗚嗚嗚/污污污”: Old driver, toot, toot, toot/dirty dirty dirty.” “Toot” and “dirty” are homophones. Later, another meaning of this term emerged: a person who is experienced in something. For example, a senior-year student may refer to himself or herself as an old driver because he or she has spent more time at a university than younger students. A veteran salesperson can also describe himself or herself as an old driver in the field.

column2: bù néng wǒ yí gè rén xiā
column3: <Expression> I can’t go blind alone. This Internet meme is used after you see gross or scary stuff online. You are so traumatized that you wish to poke your eyes out, but before you do that, you feel you must share what you saw…
adj. Hand+base. (Of hands) base. You chastise your hand or fingers for being base because you clicked on something that is so gross or scary that you regret being inquisitive.
n. Short for 人物設定 [rén wù shè dìng] character design. This internet meme is typically used in the discussion of characters in Internet novels, TV series, and movies.
n. Little+yellow+book. The yellow little book is a nickname for books and magazines characterized by either pornography or eroticism.
Love+action+movie. This Internet meme is a euphemism for porn movies or videos.
n. Boat scenes=bed scenes=sex scenes.. This Internet slang term came into popularity because “boat” and “bed” are soundalikes.

v. roll+bed sheets. Originating from a sexist belief in Northeast China that having a little boy roll on a wedding bed will help the couple conceive sons, this Internet slang term now refers to having sex.
adj. Having unsatisfied sexual desire. #Wuli污月#

v. To give out candies. This Internet slang term stems from the ritual of giving out sweets as wedding favors. Now it refers to a couple displaying affection in public or sharing details about their love. It is a positive term.
n. Curious baby. This Internet slang term is often used to describe an adult (often one’s idol) of boundless curiosity. The childlike quality is celebrated and adored.  #520告白钟汉良##科沃斯管家机器人#

n. League of Legends, a multiplayer online video game. The Chinese nickname, literally “stroke and stroke,” has a sexual connotation because of its connection with 擼管 [lū guǎn] stroke+tube [penis] or male masturbation.
n. Black mole/sunspot. As an Internet slang term, it refers to web users who vilify a celebrity on the Internet.
n. The sound of slapping or smacking. This is a euphemism for having sex.

n. Literally “small elegant butterfly,” this Internet meme became popular around 2009. It sounds like the Japanese word yamete (止めて) “stop,” which is a stereotypical female line in Japanese porn movies. The butterfly species doesn’t exist.
n. The art of facial expression, especially the acting style featuring contorted facial expressions. This Internet slang term comes from the Japanese ACG culture.
v. Sour. To make snide remarks.
adj. Poisonous. This Internet slang term is used to describe wonderful things that enthrall the audience, listeners, web users, etc.

adj. (Of a person’s limbs) weak, soft.. This Internet meme describes a charming smile or gesture that melts you heart. Reactions may include goose bumps, shivers down you spine, a tingling sensation all over your body, and a big smile on your face.

n. Canola flower/rape flower. This term is popular among Wallace Chung’s mainland fans and refers to talented fans who are creative, artistic, and/or tech-savvy. The namesake was created because it sounds like 有才華 [yǒu cái huá] “talented.”

column2: fàng kāi tā, ràng wǒ lái
column3: Get your hands off him, let me handle this. Originally a cliche line asking the kidnapper to release the hostage, this Internet slang term is now used to humorously express the desire to hug or kiss one’s favorite star.

n. Straight woman cancer. The female form of “straight man cancer,” this Internet slang term describes women who submit to sexism and actively attack women’s liberation. They deride career women, single women, childless women and mothers who don’t have sons.
adj. No feeling. Show no interest. To be not affected. This Internet slang term is used to show your disinterest in someone or something.

<Expression> There is nothing in life to long for. This Internet meme is a humorous alternative to words like “distraught,” “bummed out,” and “speechless.” A typical facial expression is actually an impassive one due to utmost frustration.

n. Trap+path. Originally the word means “routine,” “sequence,” “pattern,” “artifice,” “stratagem,” and “style.” As a new Internet meme, however, it also means “cliche,” “trap,” and “machination.” It is used to express one’s boredom with cliches or speaking patterns. It also helps express distraught after falling into someone’s trap.

column1: 我走过最远的路，是你的套路
column2: wǒ zǒu guò zuì yuǎn de lù, shì nǐ de tào lù
column3: The longest path I have ever taken, is the path to your trap.

column1: 少一点套路，多一点真诚
column2: shǎo yì diǎn tào lù, duō yì diǎn zhēn chéng
column3: Fewer schemes and more sincerity please.
v. To play in an unrestrained way. Sometimes it means to be promiscuous, to fool around.
n. Encircle+fans. To glean/accumulate fans.

n. Primeval power. Catastrophically strong physical strength. This Internet slang term came into popularity because of the 2015 TV drama The Journey of Flower in which the character Hua Qiangu aka Demon God has the preternatural, catastrophic power. Currently the meme is used to describe one’s physical strength or one’s urge to do something.

column2: fā dǒng hóng huāng zhī lǐ
column3: “To harness the premival strength”.

column1: 抵挡不住体内的洪荒之力
column2: dǐ dǎng bú zhù tǐ nèi de hóng huāng zhī lì
column3: “[I] can’t resist the primeval power in my body”.

n. 麼 [mē] is an onomatopoeia that mimics the sound of a gentle kiss aka “mwa,” [or chup in Thai, schmatz in German, mats-muts in Greek, umma in Malayalam, and chu in Japanese]. This Intenernet term imitates the form of 萌萌噠 [méng méng da] and has been a popular way among Chinese young people to show affection.

column2: zhè jù huà wǒ gěi mǎn fēn
column3: <Expression> I give this sentence full marks. This phrase is used to compliment someone who says something that greatly pleases the listener. A variation is 這句話我給99分，多一份怕你驕傲 [zhè jù huà wǒ gěi jiǔ shí jiǔ fēn, duō yì fēn pà nǐ jiāo ào] I give this sentence 99 points; if I give you one more point, I am afraid you will be too proud.

v. To know how to chat. A conversationalist who is polite, respectful, understanding, and interesting is touted as someone who knows how to chat. This Internet slang term celebrates one’s high EQ. In the Chinese Internet culture, a high IQ is predominately defined as being polite and considerate of others.

v. To not know how to chat. A person who doesn’t know how to chat tends to offend others intentionally or unintentionally. This Internet slang term is often used humorously as a mild criticism of the lack of consideration of others’ feelings.
v. Originating from Japan and South Korea,  応援 or 응원, this Internet slang term means to help and support [the idol].
n. Boyfriend+strength. The likelihood of being an ideal boyfriend.
n. Perfect boyfriend material. This Internet slang term describes both men and women who make a woman feel safe, loved, and happy.
v. To occupy the screen. You use this Internet slang term to describe an actor whose works you can see everywhere on TV and in movie theaters.
n. I, the baby. Referring to oneself as a baby. This Internet slang term is used by young people to play cute. (Digital illustration by Kim Smith)

column1: 明明可以靠脸吃饭, 偏偏要靠才华
column2: míng míng kě yǐ kào liǎn chī fàn, piān piān yào kào cái huá
column3: <Expression> [Someone] could have clearly had meals with the face, but he/she chose to do so with talents and skills. “Have meals” means “make a living.” This expression means “[someone] could have made a living easily with his or her good appearance, but he/she insists on utilizing his or her talents and skills.” The expression is used to show recognition of someone’s becoming appearance and volition to learn skills and work hard.
n. Fan+sister. Female fanatics. Fervent female fans.
n. Fan+brother. Male fanatics. Fervent male fans.

column2: jié cāo diào le yí dì
column3: Expression. Integrity is scattered all over the floor. This Internet slang term often describes people who do unconventional things that are not necessarily unethical. Considered reckless, silly or even brash by the outsiders, those “out-of-place” acts are usually done out of passion, such as what fans would do for idols or what an infatuated person would do for his or her crush.
n. Chan. This word is added after a child’s name or a close friend’s name to show affection in Japanese, but Chinese young people (especially Japanese culture lovers) like using the word too.
n. New show. Originally it referred to new Japanese animation-manga TV series, now it describes any new TV show or movie.
n. The peak of physical attractiveness.

n. Brainwashing+epic+song. A pop song whose melody and lyrics are catchy and memorable. When it is stuck in your head, it can stay there for days. Sometimes this Internet slang term is slightly negative because the music is often not considered very classy.
v. To break into smithereens. This Internet slang term is often used to describe a broken heart or the challenged worldview, but exaggeration, humor, and/or sarcasm are involved in the usage.
<Expression> Live+long+see. If you live long enough, you will be able to witness all kinds of things (however unbelievable or bizarre they are).
adj. Burn+brain. Brain-scorching. This Internet slang term means “intellectually challenging”.

n./adj. Ghost+beast. To inflict suffering. Originally an ACG term, this neologism often refers to a video editing technique that pieces together dialogue and background music for humorous value. Some sounds are looped at a high speed, which might cause discomfort.
adj. Dumbstruck, dumbfounded, muddled, perplexed, flustered..

A site aka Acfun. B站 [B zhàn] B site aka bilibili. Both are interactive video sharing websites themed around anime, manga, game, movie, music, and TV fandom based in China. They also both feature “barrage,” a real-time on-screen user commentary system.

n. Phoenix man. This Internet slang term refers to self-made men of humble roots. This group has been widely discussed because of their marital conflicts typically with “peacock women” and their emotional enmeshment with their families of origin. The implication is negative.

n. Peacock woman. This Internet slang term refers to women raised in well-off families in the cities. This group has been widely discussed because of their marital conflicts typically with “phoenix men” on cultural differences and financial matters. The implication is negative.

n. Keyboard+knight-errant. People who like going on a rant on the Internet. They are cynical and judgmental without the ability to make a difference through action. 噴 [pēn] v. To spurt, spout, gush. This Internet slang term means “to go on a rant,” often used to describe Internet trolls.
n. Raw meat. Foreign language videos without Chinese subtitles.
n. Cooked meat. Foreign language videos with Chinese subtitles.
Little Lee, an affectionate nickname for Leonardo Dicaprio. It is also a common nickname for an eunuch whose family name is Li in TV series about the imperial palace of the Qing dynasty.
n. Dog food. This neologism refers to the self-pity of single people (humorously dubbed “single dogs“) triggered by the public displays of affection by couples online or offline.
v. To talk sheer nonsense; to ramble on; to nag; to gossip; to judge others.

column2: nǐ xíng nǐ shàng, bù xíng bié xiā bī bī
column3: Expression. If you can do it then you should go up and do it, otherwise you’d better keep your mouth shut.
v. To tease (someone). The word used to mean “to take liberties with (a woman)”, but as an Internet slang term, it means “to tease someone for wholesome fun”.
<Expression> Pouring out dirtiness in a steady flow. This expression is used to describe people who like talking about sex either directly or indirectly.
n. Hehehe. Lewd laughter. A euphemism for lovemaking used by Taiwanese entertainer Fei Yu-ching in one of his sex jokes on TV.

adj. Dirty. This neologism is used to tease someone that tells sex jokes. It is also used to comment on sexually explicit content. Humor is involved in the usage and the user doesn’t really abhor the sex puns or lewd talk.

v. Originally referring to playing dirty in video games through a cheat code or a cheat cartridge, this Internet slang term is an alternative way of saying “[someone] is on fire/doing an incredibly great job as if she or he were cheating”.
n. Fraud caliber. The ability to make people think you are better than you really are.
n. People of Chaoyang District [in Beijing]. Residents of this area are famous crime-busters who actively report suspicious activity to the police to ensure community safety.

column1: 我伙呆 (=我和小伙伴都惊呆了)
column2: wǒ huǒ dāi (=wǒ hé xiǎo huǒ bàn men dōu jīng dāi le)
column3: <Expression> My little buddies [“little buddies” is used among children to refer to friends] and I were all dumbfounde. This expression is often used humorously to express one’s shock at something.

n. Emoji package. A humorous picture or GIF used in online conversations as an emoji. The image is often captioned.  Celebrities’ pictures of exaggerated facial expressions are often captioned as emojis.
adj. Written in bold and all caps. This Internet slang term is used to emphasize the words that come thereafter.
adj. Candid, honest and outspoken, not worried about one’s own image or others’ feelings. This Internet slang term can be either positive or negative.
n. Scruples, moral principles, integrity. This slang term is often used in teasing and joking.

column2: cóng cǐ jié cāo shì lù rén
column3: <Expression> Scruples have since been passers-by. This expression means making unconventional choices would distance you from the social norms widely observed by the consertative people. For example, when one develops a hobby of reading or watcing Boy’s Love anime, he or she may be more likely to appeciate unconventional ideas about dating and relationships.
n. Star-chasing dogs. Fanatic fans [of artists and entertainers such as singers and actors].
v. To hit on a woman, to do something rather purposefully to attract women’s attention. This Internet slang term comes from Taiwan.
v. Titillate+sister. 1) To do something snazzy to attract the female audience’s attention. 2) To hit on a female to steal her heart.

City+can+play. This Internet slang term is short for “urban residents know how to have fun”. You use it when you are amused by people’s attempt to entertain themselves. Sometimes it is used sarcastically.
n./v. Meaningless, rapid talk; an idle chatter; gabble; nagging.

n. Scheming, shrewd boy/girl. This Internet slang term is used to describe a person whose behaviors are self-serving. It can be used positively to tease a friend or an idol or negatively to criticize someone.

v. To chat about life, a humorous euphemism for “I disagree,” “Are you kidding me,” and “Are you out of your mind. ” This Internet slang term is used when you find people’s words or actions silly or perplexing and you want to tease them a little bit.
v. Come out. A humorous phonetic deviation of 出來 [chū lái] “come out”.
n. Mori (Forest) girl. In Japanese, a mori girl is a girl who looks like she lives in forests. She is dressed in earthy colors and pursues a simple and natural lifestyle.
v. To lick the screen. To drool over the online photos or videos of sexy people or scrumptious food.
n. 1. Illustrators who use touch-enabled devices and pressure-sensitive pens. 2. ACG illustrators.
& 鐵粉 [tiě fěn] n. Dead+loyal+fan. Iron+fan. Both Internet slang terms mean “hardcore fans, stalwarts”.
v. To roll out a significant gambit. To make a big and possibly risky move to achieve the desired result.
adj./n. Stern-faced. A stern face.
~= 我喜歡你 [wǒ xǐ huān nǐ] Expression.. This Internet slang phrase is a cute way of saying “I like/dig/love you” with a Taiwanese Mandarin accent.

column2: 。。。bú shì gāo lěng, zhǐ shì nuǎn de bú shì nǐ
column3: <Expression> [Someone] is not cold and aloof—it’s just that you are not the one he/she cares about. This Internet slang phrase is used to comment on the fact that someone is not that into you.

column1: 妈妈问我为什么跪著看。。。
column2: mā ma wèn wǒ wèi shén me guì zhe kàn。。。
column3: Mom asked me why I watch…on my knees. This Internet slang term is used to describe a mind-blowing or mind-boggling video or other content.
adj. Doesn’t not do harm to either human beings or animals. Innocuous. This Internet slang term is used to describe a person who is kind and innocent and maybe occasionally naive.
<Expression> Nobody can beat that. This Internet slang term is often used ironically to comment on unique or controversial people or behavior.
n. Party. The word literally means lying on one’s stomach, but as an Internet slang term, it means “party” because of the similar pronunciation.
n. Christmas party.
n. Bomb+lie on one’s stomach. Home party. This Internet slang term is a translation of the English term “home party” because 轟 [hōng] sounds like “home” and 趴 [pā] sounds like “party.”
n. The seller’s demo.
n. The customer’s demo.
v. Buy buy buy! This Internet slang term is often used humorously to convey or provoke a strong desire to splurge.
<Expression> The reflex arc is too long. Slow reflexes/response. This Internet slang term is used to describe the situation where it took someone a while to discover or realize something.

column2: péi bàn, shì zuì cháng qíng de gào bái
column3: <Expression> Staying as one’s companion is the most perennial love confession.
v. Car+quake. To have sex in a car.

n. Bump+china. Extortion under false pretence. As an Internet slang term, its latest meaning is that old people deliberately lying down in front of vehicles pretending to be injured and then asking vehicle owners for compensation.
adj. Bashful. This Internet slang term is often used humorously to describe males.

column2: ……de zhèng què dǎ kāi fāng shì
column3: The right way of opening… This Internet slang term is an alternate way of saying “how to do…(in my opinion)” or “the right way of interpreting…(in my opinion)”.
adv. Witty like me. This Internet slang term is used to precede crediting oneself with accomplishing a task or avoiding a contretemps. This term is often used ironically.
<Expression> [With one’s] dream as a horse. Originally the title of a poem by Hai Zi, this Internet slang term is now used by hipsters to show their dedication to their dreams.

column1: 自己挖的坑，跪著也要填完
column2: zì jǐ wā de kēng, guì zhe yě yào tián wán
column3: <Expression> Since the hole is digged by myself, I have to fill it even if that means kneeling on the ground throughout the process. This Internet slang term means that, once you make a decision or commitment, you have to pay the dues no matter what.

n. To flip the name plates. In ancient China, the emperor chose who to serve him at night by flipping the name plates of consorts. It is now a metaphor for being responded by someone you admire (such as your favorite star) on Weibo or being chosen to meet or interact with him or her.

column2: shàng bèi zi zhěng jiù le yín hé xì
column3: Rescued the Milky Way in one’s previous life. This Internet slang phrase is used to express your envy or jealousy toward the people who got something you desire. You joke that their good luck implies good karma.
To be honest, honestly, seriously.
n. Dark cuisine. Bizarre foods or weird food combinations that look distasteful.

adj. Strong-flavored. This Internet slang term is used to describe unconventional practices or artworks that are obscure or unpopular with the average people or mainstream audiences. Some may cause discomfort. E.g. BDSM, fetishism, eating bizarre foods.

column2: yí dà bō jiāng shī zhèng zài jiē jìn
column3: A huge wave of zombies is approaching. This is a famous line in the game Plants vs. Zombies. 一大波 [yí dà bō] “A huge wave/crop of…” is now an Internet slang term commonly seen in news. Pics: World Zombie Day

n. Turnover, an abrupt change; a reversal. 劇情反轉 [jù qíng fǎn zhuǎn] n. Plot twist. A plot twist is an unexpected change in the storyline of a novel, film, television series, comic, video game, news story, etc.

Hold me tight. This phrase is used after voicing an opinion to invite others to side with you. It is also used to ask others to tell you if they had the same experience as you did. It originated in a weibo uproar in February, 2015 concerning a dress of disputed colors.

n. Punch line, joke.. This Internet slang term originally comes from Xiangsheng aka Crosstalk, a Chinese comedic performance, but it is made popular online through Taiwanese talk shows like Kangxi Lai Le aka Kangsi Coming. #Cai Kangyong and Little S Bid Farewell to Kangsi Coming# #蔡康永小S告别康熙#
n. An aura of 2. 8 meters. This Internet slang term is used to describe a person with an aura of respectability. It is often used humorously.
adj. carry+feeling. This Internet slang term is used to describe people or things that touch your heart, pique your interest, and/or bring you joy.
n. The inner drama. This Internet slang term describes the unsaid thoughts and feelings that one has. The inner drama is often communicated through microexpressions.

n. The princess syndrome. This negative Internet slang term is used to describe women who are high-maintenance and demand to be treated like a princess. They are self-centered, temperamental, needy, attention-seeking, and often fall victim to consumerism.
n. Perks, giveaways. This Internet slang term is used to describe the benefits or gifts received for carrying certain identities.

v. [Gaming terminology] To attack a dying person once more to make sure he or she will definitely die. Similar to “rub salt in the wound,” this Internet slang term is later used to describe further mocking or rebuttal in communication.

adj. Of, Dog+blood. 1) Since dog blood was often used for exorcism in Hong Kong horror film scenes, it became an Internet meme to describe trite and highly predictable movie or TV drama scenes; 2) of, relating to ludirously unrealistic movie or TV drama scenes; 3) of, relating to, or characterized by schmaltz, dramatized sentimentalism, as in TV shows and movies; 4) of, relating to life events that are ridiculous and infuriating.
adj. adv. & n. Spoil+indulge. Indulgent, indulgently, loving indulgence.

n. Uncle Xi. This Internet slang term was created by 張洪銘 Zhang Hongming as a nickname for Xi Jinping, the President of China. Zhang explained that 大大 [dà dà] is a way of addressing a paternal uncle younger than one’s father in Shaanxi dialects.

n. A phonetic variation of 小公主 [xiǎo gōng zhǔ] “the little princess”. This Internet slang term refers to a man who does not follow the traditional gender role as a macho guy. He is not afraid to display the “feminine” body language.
v. Fragmented+fragmented+talk. 1) To chatter/prattle/jabber; 2) to nag; 3) to mutter.

n. Next door+Old Wang. Mr. Wang who lives next door. This Internet slang term has two meanings: 1) The secret lover of one’s wife. 2) Someone else’s husband whom a woman often deems better than her own. She often annoyingly compares her own husband with that alpha male neighbor/friend/acquaintance hoping to inspire the husband to catch up with the “role model.”

adj. Having a propensity to nag at others, to talk about people behind their backs, or to simply speak impolitely or even offensively. This Internet slang term is used to describe people who lack respect for others, hurt others’ feelings, or don’t know how to hold a friendly and delightful conversation.
adv. To use one’s life to [do something]. To [do something] wholeheartedly/with no reservation. This Internet slang term is often used humorously.
adj. Chicken+frozen.. This Internet slang term and 激動 [jī dòng] “excited” are homophones and synonyms.

column2: bà dào zǒng cái ài shàng wǒ
column3: <Expression> The overbearing executive fell in love with me. This Internet slang term describes a trending patriarchal storyline in Chinese and Korean TV shows: A domineering upper-class man being attracted to a working-class woman.

n. Imperious+executive. This Internet slang term refers to a chauvinist male character in romance novels and TV shows—he is a rich, powerful, and fatally attractive control freak who has a soft spot for a rather unlikely female love interest.

n. A winner in life. A person who achieves or even exceeds the mainstream definition of success. In China, such a person is typically heterosexual, nice-looking, highly educated, incredibly rich and/or powerful, married, and has one or more adorable children.

v. YY is a pinyin acronym for 意淫 [yì yín]. 1) To fantasize; 2) to have sexual fantasies; 3) to have unrealistic expectations. 4) to interpret things in narcissistic ways. 歪 [wāi] means crooked, slanted, and evil.

column2: qiú…de xīn lǐ yīn yǐng miàn ji
column3: <Expression> Determine the size of [someone’s] psychological shadow. Determine how traumatized someone is. This Internet slang term is used to poke fun at someone assumed to be embarrassed or hurt in a situation. For example, when you see your neighbor constantly chastise his kid by comparing the little child with the smartest kid in the class, you lament that you don’t know how traumatized the child will be by such an overbearing parent.

n. Originally きしかん in Japanese meaning “déjà vu”, the illusion of having previously experienced something actually being encountered for the first time. As an Internet slang term, it simply means “[someone or something] looks like/feels like…”
v. To spaz out. To go into hysterics on someone.  To overreact and seek attention. To make a fuss about small things. n. Histrionics.

n. An idol’s baggage. This Internet slang term refers to the the fear of losing fans that causes artists or celebrities to hide their true selves in public. They might hold fast to the established image on purpose to maintain popularity.

n. Face-looking world. A world that prioritizes appearance. A world that favors good appearance. This Internet slang term is sometimes an example of the fundamental attribution error: Attributing personal setbacks to the cultural obsession with appearance.

n. Face+freak. A person who is obsessed with good-looking people and believes that beauty can give one a head start in life. They might have a conscious or unconscious bias against plain-looking people.

n. Hand-chopping gang. White-collar consumers whose obsessive online shopping sprees result in long bills. In hindsight, they are so guilty that they want to chop off their own hands to prevent themselves from placing orders on the Internet.

n. Silly+innocent+sweet. Originally used to describe an unaffected, sweet and innocent female character in romance novels, this Internet slang term now applies to people of all genders and ages who are genuinely adorable.

<Expression> I want some quiet time. This Internet slang term is used to when you are shocked. The expression is sometimes followed by 別問我靜靜是誰 [bié wèn wǒ jìng jìng shì shuí] Don’t ask me who Jingjing is, because an alternative interpretation of the expression is “I miss Jingjing.”

n. Appearance+association. The good looks club. This Internet slang term was first used to describe women who pick dates or spouses based on their looks—handsomeness outweighs everything else. Now it also refers to a preference for aesthetic qualities.

v. To use too much strength. A Chinese equivalent of the idiom “cross the line” in English. This Internet slang term describes well-intended yet inappropriate efforts that turn out to be counterproductive or socially unacceptable.

v. To make a fancy display of the intimacy between a couple. This Internet slang term is created from the perspective of single people who feel left out in the face of couples especially on Valentine’s Day.
v. Fancy+abuse+dogs. To hurt the feelings of single people [single dogs] knowingly or unknowingly through myriad forms of public display of affection.
v. To abuse [single] dogs. To deliberately or unknowingly tease or hurt the single people through public displayed affection online or offline.
<Expression> Cannot bear to look at [someone or something] straight in the eye. This Internet slang term is used when you find it hard to accept a situation.
n. A god/goddess. This Internet slang term is often used to describe one’s idol or love interest, usually of stunning looks and/or talents. Hyperbole is employed here to show one’s admiration.
n. / adj. (Of the) therapeutic+series. Originated from the Japanese phrase 癒し系, this Internet slang term describes people and things that are healing, calming, and heartwarming.

n. Negative energy. People or things that are of or cause toxic emotions like excessive and/or unnecessary guilt, shame, anger, self-loathing, depression, regret, bitterness, jealousy, and resentment. Negative energy saps people of their motivation and strength.
v./n. To counterattack, to reverse the score, to catch up and eventually taking the lead.

n. Glass+heart. Glass-like fragile heart. This Internet slang term is used to judge someone who is hypersensitive and emotionally vulnerable. It also alludes to low self-esteem. The term is sometimes used to describe oneself for humorous effect.
Actually, not really. This Internet slang term is often used to defy someone else’s presumption humorously.

n. Snake+spirit+disease. Adapted from 神經病 [shén jīng bìng] “a neurotic person or a person with a mental disorder”, the Internet slang term often describes a creatively wacky and often funny person. It can be a compliment.

What the devil [is that/are you talking about]? This Internet slang term is often coupled with this emoticon [笑cry] which means 笑cry [xiào cry] “laugh to the point of crying”. You don’t use this term when you are mad or upset or confused; use it when you are amused.
adj. Feeling pumped and inspired.

column2: shēn yè fā chī, bào fù shè huì
column3: Expression.
n. Excrement, feces, poop.
Scare the crap out of me.

n. The national husband of China. This Internet slang term usually refers to Wang Sicong. The 27-year-old man is the son of Wang Jianlin, a Chinese businessman and philanthropist who is currently the richest person in China and Asia.

adj. Self-willed, obstinately doing what one wants in spite of social norms or the expectations of others. This Internet slang term is often used to elucidate or defend one’s independence or uniqueness in mind and action.
v. To slap one’s own face. To behave in ways that contradict one’s previous statements; to have one’s claims contradicted by the truth.

n. Dreg+male. This Internet slang term usually refers to dissolute and licentious men who are disloyal in love, but it also describes men who don’t work hard for career advancement. Sometimes it is another way of describing the male chauvinist pigs.

n. Green tea+bitch. An ostensibly graceful and innocent young woman who is actually very calculating. This Internet slang term was created in 2013 to describe models and actresses who lead a dissipated life around the rich and powerful for personal gain.

v. Friend+over. To sever a friendship. This Internet slang term is often used as a humorous reply to a friend’s prank or offensive comment or a joking comment on a friend’s amazing strength that makes you feel sorry for your mediocrity. Yet, sometimes people do mean it when they say to you, “Friendship terminated.”

v. Pull+hatred. [Gaming terminology] To attract the monsters to attack oneself. As an Internet slang term, it means to deliberately boast or to say potentially offensive things. It typically refers to boasting in ways that could induce jealousy.

n. Tap water. This Internet slang term refers to the Internet users who voluntarily post laudatory remarks online to promote a brand. This term was originally used to describe the viewers of Monkey King: Hero’s Back who recommend the movie on the Internet.
v. Literally “to irrigate,” this Internet slang term is a metaphor for posting tasteless messages online.

v. Literally “waterborne troops,” this Internet slang term refer to the rumored people hired by PR firms for online marketing purposes. They post online to either support a brand or sabotage the brand’s competition.
v. To blacken. This Internet slang term means to mock or tease a friend or to bash, malign, or vilify one’s enemy.
n. Wolf+people. Lustful citizens. A nickname for Wallace Chung’s fans 良民 “good citizens”. The nickname was created based on some Wallace fans’ unapologetic vehement admiration for their idol.

<Expression> Your distinguished field is so chaotic. This Internet slang term is often used to describe the entertainment industry which is believed to be fraught with unspoken rules regarding power struggle for fame and fortune.

v. Paint+screen. To publish several posts on the homepage or News Feeds page on a social media site within a short time, which sometimes exasperates the followers. 被……刷屏 [bèi shuā píng] v. To have the homepage occupied by posts by someone or about a topic.
adj. [Having an] acid tongue; to be inclined to be make acerbic comments that are likely to hurt people’s feelings.
n. Rich people.. 2) adj. Rich, luxurious. Sometimes this Internet slang term indicates a sense of contempt for the rich people who are uneducated and ill-mannered.
n. Internet celebrity, cyberstar.
adj./n. Industry+conscience. Of the industry standard.
<Expression> Vigorously+swipe+[the] presence [card]. To have a strong presence. To stand out and impress others. This Internet slang term is sometimes used sarcastically.
v. As an Internet slang term, the Chinese translation of Amway means “to advertise something or someone that one adores to others, sometimes in defiance of others’ disinterest”.
<Expression> So tired that I feel I will not fall in love anymore.
adj. Abuse+heart. Heart-wrenching.

column2: xiào de xiàng zhōng hàn liáng yí yàng
column3: To laugh as Wallace Chung does.
adj. Monster+nature. Having a magical pull, captivating. This Internet slang term is sometimes used sarcastically.

adj. Originated from the Japanese ACG [Anime, Comic and Games] sub-culture, “tsundere” [ツンデレ] describes a person who is initially cold and even hostile towards another person before gradually showing their warm and even coy side over time. Now the term is also used to mean “sassy”.

n. [Fan fiction terminology] Mary Sue, an idealized character. The male equivalent is Gary Stu or Marty Stu. A a poorly developed female character, too perfect and lacking in realism to be interesting.

n. True love+fan. Fanatic fans whose love for the idol stands the test of time. They often regard the idol as a mentor and major influence, express their devotion creatively, and strive to become a better person as a result.

n. Highlights ahead. Originating from the Japanese ACG (anime, comic and games) culture, this Internet slang term asks the readers to pay attention to what comes next. It often precedes a spoiler alert or an interesting fact.

n. Deep in the closet+male. Homosexual males who haven’t come out. They claim to be heterosexual and sometimes display anti-homosexual attitudes. Some of them date and/marry the opposite sex under social pressure and keep their sexual orientation a secret.
<Expression> The fans and their idols share similar qualities [in terms of personality and interests].
To be waken up by one’s handsomeness.
<Expression> My bad? So you think it is my fault? The person who uses this Internet slang term usually doesn’t think he or she is to blame.

adj. Short for 精神分裂 [jīng shén fēn liè] schizophrenia. As an Internet slang term, it means showing two or more personalities or being dazzled by a fickle and annoying person or unexpected changes. It is often used humorously.

adj. Proud and detached. This Internet slang term is often used to describe someone who is mature, calm, reserved, stern, and aloof. Those qualities can be either enigmatic or annoying, depending on how much you like the person. Sometimes the term is a euphemism for “you cocky bastard”.
v. To fall into water. A metaphor for becoming Wallace Chung’s fans. 落水文 [luò shuǐ wén] n. An essay on falling into water—an essay that a new fan wrote about how he or she became a Wallace fan.
n. Wallace Chung aka Zhong Hanliang’s fans—Liang’s people aka good citizens. Their motto is: Get closer to his [Wallace Chung’s] works; stay farther away from his personal life.
adj. Criminally cute, cuteness overload.

v. & n. Tear up+vagina. This sexist Internet slang term originally referred to caustic quarrels between women, but now it has evolved to describe acrimonious disputes or tough competition between people or organizations.
v. Pedestrian+turn+fan. To change from being a pedestrian [nonfan] to being a fan. This Internet slang term is often used by an entertainer’s new fans to describe their conversion or attitude change.

v. Wall+slapping sound. Originally “kabe-don” [かべドン] in the Japanese anime, this Internet slang term refers to a man forcing a woman against a wall with one hand OR leaning against a wall, making a slapping sound, and leaving the woman nowhere to go.
n. Reverse+growth. This Internet slang term is used to describe someone whose appearance (almost) does not show signs of aging over a span of years.
<Expression> No! No! This phrase is originally related to Japanese porn movies. 萌得不要不要的 Unbearably cute that it makes you say “No! No!” or “Stop! Stop!”

A sudden change in the painting style. This Internet slang term is often used to accentuate the contrast between one’s responses in different situations. It also refers to an unexpected twist in the story. Humor is often involved in the context where this term is applied.
n. Painting style. This Internet slang term is often used to describe one’s style in appearance and behavior or the vibes in an environment.

n. Brain+hole. As an Internet slang term, this is a vivid metaphor for imagination or creativity. 腦洞太大 “Having a super big hole in the brain” renders a person amusingly or ridiculously imaginative and creative. Sometimes this term is used sarcastically.

column2: shào nǚ xīn shōu gē jī
column3: n. Teen girls’ hearts+harvester. Male actors or singers who captivate female audiences with their good looks and/or talents.
<Video game terminology> The blood groove is already empty. Death. This Internet slang term is often used to describe how people are swept off their feet by the pictures of their idols.
v. Cancel+follow. To unfollow [someone on a social media site].
adj. Adorkable. Both dorky/silly and adorable. This Internet slang term is used lovingly.
n. <Expletive> A phonetic variation of 小婊子 [xiǎo biǎo zi] “little bitch” with the Beijing accent.
v. Pretend+vagina.. To aggrandize oneself, to put on a charade of wealth and/or wisdom, to make oneself look richer, more powerful, more intelligent, and more important than he or she really is.

n. Little+definite+happiness. Little things that you can be sure of and will make you happy. Quoted from Haruki Murakami’s book Afternoon of the Islets of Langerhans to refer to transient happiness, this Internet slang term reminds people to be grateful.

n. Rotten+female. This Internet slang term originated from ふじょし [fujoshi, readers of male-male romance narratives]. In China, it refers to female consumers of TV shows, movies, novels, etc. about BL [Boys’ Love] aka emotional (and sexual) intimacy among young men.

n. & v. street+leak. Though identical with the Chinese translation of Reuters, this Internet slang term refers to spoiler alerts by the fans of celebrities who are working on a reality TV show, movie, etc.
Maxing out the cute-o-meter. Off-the-charts cute/pretty.
n. Literally “single dog”, this Internet slang term refers to single people who are eager to enter a relationship but find it difficult to achieve the goal.
n. New skill. This Internet slang term is often followed by “快get” [kuài get] which means “get [the new skill] quickly”. The skills discussed are often inspired by creativity.
n. A woman’s male confidante.
n. Meow star folks. Cats, kittes. Dogs or puppies are called 汪星人[wāng xīng rén] woof star folks.
n. Clown, hoot. An amusing person.
<Expression>.
v. To bend [someone]. To turn a heterosexual person into a homosexual. Sometimes this Internet slang term is used to praise a charming person of the same sex.
adj. Walk+heart. Going through one’s heart. Sincere, from the bottom of one’s heart, [a project] showing diligence and dedication and moving the reader or the audience.
v. & n. 1. Fierce verbal fights; 2. Malicious competition or intrigues.
<Expression> I’m drunk too/I got wasted too.

column1: 还能不能愉快地玩耍了
column2: hái néng bù néng yú kuài de wán shuǎ le
column3: Expression.
n. Little+fresh+flesh. Spring chicken. This Internet slang term refers to teens or young adults who are nice-looking (especially with impeccable skin) and look innocent.

column1: 不作死就不会死 (No Zuo No Die)
column2: bù zuō sǐ jiù bú huì sǐ (no zuō no die)
column3: <Expression> If you don’t seek death, you won’t die. If you don’t do stupid things, you won’t suffer. This phrase is often used to comment on crazy behaviors that lead to embarrassment and awkwardness.

column2: gǎn jué zì jǐ méng méng da
column3: <Expression> [I] feel that [I] am such a peach. This Internet slang phrase went popular recently as a way of complimenting oneself or others for being adorable, playing cute, or doing funny things.
v./adj. To gloat; cocky.
adj. All kinds of. This Internet slang term is usually followed by an adjective.
n. Black lines. The emoticon is used to indicate embarrassment.
~= 非常 [fēi cháng] Gray+usual. Very, extremely.. This Internet slang term is a humorous way of saying 非常 [fēi cháng] “very” with a Fujian accent.
adv. Literally “every minute”, this Internet slang term means “instantly”.

adj. Little+clear+fresh. 1. A music genre marked by artistic, aesthetic, and nonmainstream compositions and/or lyrics. 2. The artistic, aesthetic, and nonmainstream style in literature, movie, and photography. 3. [Of people] adoring simplicity, elegance, serenity, and independence. Sometimes this Internet slang is used with sarcasm.
~=这样子 [zhè yàng zi] With this…/doing this.. This Internet slang term mimics the Taiwanese way of saying the phrase 这样子 [zhè yàng zi].
n. Professor Du, referring to Do Min-joon from the South Korean TV show My Love from the Star which was tremendously popular in China in 2013.
n. Internet joke or quip writer.
adj. Brain+disabled. Literally “brain-damaged”, this slang term is often used to laugh at a person who is ludicrous, dumb, or weird.
n. A gay person, a homosexual man. Contingent on the context, this Internet slang term can be either neutral or negative.
n. This dude, often used in causal conversation among Chinese young people.
n./adj. Weirdo. Goofy, wacky, zany.

v. “Lying down [but still got] shot. ” Short for 躺著也中槍 [tǎng zhe yě zhòng qiāng] “getting shot while lying [on the floor]”, this Internet slang term is used to describe people being criticized or mentioned in an unwanted way even when they deliberately try to avoid it. People mentioned or blamed for what they are not responsible for often use this Internet slang term for self-mockery.
adj. Feeling crushed, having an emotional meltdown.
adj. So sad that it makes you cry. This Internet slang term is often used to describe something that’s shocking, sad and hard to accept.

column2: rén shēng kǔ duǎn bì xū xìng gǎn
column3: <expression> Life is short, [one] must be sexy.. This expression is widely used to encourage people to be brave. As 短 [duǎn] “short” rhymes with 性感 [xìng gǎn] “sexy”, I prefer to translate it as “life is short, get some balls.”
v. Laugh [so hard that I] wet my pants.
n. Literally “laughing point,” this slang term refers to how easy it is to make someone burst into laughter. An easily amused person has a low laughing point.
v. To be brimming with swagger. This Internet slang term is sometimes used sarcastically to refer to someone who blatantly violates social norms or makes a showy display of his or her abilities.

n. Cold joke. Similar to brain teasers, cold jokes are funny because they urge the listeners to think outside the box. Homophones, Chinese words with multiple meanings, and linguistic deviations like personification are often included in cold jokes.
<Expression> The maven is among the folks. This sentence is often used to describe the average Chinese people who are capable of jaw-dropping stunts.
